generation: Another week flew by. I drove past the new house yesterday—the front window was covered in boxes. We may get the keys at closing; I’m thrilled. If all goes well, we’ll close a week from Wednesday. Last night, Bethany and I stayed up past 3:00am watching movies. Lately, we’ve been watching a lot of films. Here’s the rundown: we saw *Thirteen*, a must-watch for mothers of teens—better than expected. Then *Gigli*—just as bad as the reviews said, but we had to see for ourselves.

Summer TV used to be a dead zone full of repeats, but now there are two great new shows I’ve been watching religiously. *Blow Out*—the gayest concept ever with seemingly zero gay people in sight. Hairstylist Jonathan Antin wants to open a second location of his popular West Hollywood salon, this time in Beverly Hills. Normally, no one would care—certainly not me—but as I flipped through channels, I caught a glimpse of Jonathan, equally narcissistic and dull, staring at an empty space on Rodeo Dr. declaring (loudly), "I’m going to build the greatest salon in history!" And I was hooked. Not since Rocco has such a moron made for compelling TV.

What a week... My right shoulder has tendonitis right under the shoulder blade. Moving my arm too much, especially while using a computer mouse, is agonizing. I overdid it while updating my website and handling other online tasks, so now I can barely move it. Drawing feels impossible, and sleep deprivation worsens the pain. I’m not too happy, but I’ll recover. My mom’s surgery went well—her eyesight has improved slightly. She can see blurred shapes and distinguish colors, though she remains mostly blind. Hopefully, her vision will fully return soon.

Kindness of strangers... Attempted laundry today with the kids in tow and realized how quickly the simplest things can become an ordeal. I also learned how remarkably sweet strangers can be for no reason other than kindness. Trust me, it wasn’t like they were trying to get into my pants—I had kid drool all over me and was wearing my 'wash-day' outfit. Also, I’m not sure I’ll ever bathe again, so there wasn’t even an olfactory incentive! Right now, I’m composing a post while watching No Doubt videos at my desk.

It's 11:14 PM MST, and I'm sitting in my bedroom fixing the personnel director's computer from work. I don't mind helping, but I often wonder how frequently I end up repairing someone else's device as a favor. I enjoy serving people this way, but when does it cross into being taken advantage of? Lately, I've been staying up late reading and was hoping to turn in early tonight—until I realized I should return this computer promptly. *laugh* No rest for the weary, right? So here I am rewatching *Joe Schmo 2* instead.

Remind me, what did I write about before this? Or, a continuation of the 'Is this a date?' saga. After the awkward lunch, my confidence wavered, and I forgot to share a key detail. Before Pat arrived, Dustin started praising him, mentioning how he wanted to find him a girlfriend. As I listened and nodded, it dawned on me that we were focusing more on setting Pat up than having a normal conversation with a stranger over lemonade. I excused myself to the bathroom, glanced in the mirror, and wondered: Am I being pawned off to his friend? Is this really happening?

I would like everyone to think before they act. Actually, I'd like every single person in the world to consider their choices before getting out of bed each morning and commit to staying thoughtful all day. If they aren’t willing to, I’d prefer they just stay in bed and drift into eternal slumber. I'm exhausted by foolishness. No, I'm not the smartest person alive, but I'm not discussing complex matters—just basic reasoning, so it’s fair to criticize sheer stupidity. Let’s focus this rant on a few specific types today and save the rest for later. Sound good? Great.

Two issues with the scenario I outlined earlier:  
1. While Bush is stimulating the economy, his approach is flawed. As Robert Rubin noted on NPR’s *Marketplace*, the same effect could have been achieved with temporary tax cuts targeting low- and middle-income earners, avoiding long-term debt. Ah, Rubin—his name alone inspires confidence. Can you name a Bush cabinet official with comparable gravitas? Still thinking?  
2. Granting Republicans wartime control is risky—they’ve crafted an endless "war on terror.

'She's saying I'm on the run, I'm chasing guys for fun' ~The Offspring. Haven’t updated in a while, but not much to say. Went to The Cove to see Supernothing—they were great as always, and got to hang with Tiago :-). Saturday: worked, then went out with Joe and Rach. Met up with Steve, Tiago, and Tom. Got home around 11:45 PM and woke up at 6:45 AM for a meet. Arrived slightly late, but it went well—full routine on floor (no falls!), second on floor and vault, third on beam. Scored 29.45 all-around, which is decent since I improve as the season progresses.

Do you ever have one of those moments when you start reflecting on life? Like sitting in math class, utterly bored, and wondering how your brain even processes math? Then it hits you—you exist, you're in math class, and you question why. Suddenly, you marvel at how incredible existence is, only to realize how absurd this train of thought is. Ever experienced that? I despise it. And you know what else I hate? Block schedules. Who thought that was a good idea? Enduring a two-and-a-half-hour class in any subject is pure torture.

I think that **monopoly** has run **its** course in my life, and I vow never to **touch** that **cursed** iron (not a hot one but the piece in the game) again. Tonight, Andy beat me by a few **dollars** and won the **friggin'** game—or maybe I let him win, since he’s leaving in a few hours and I wanted him to feel good on his last night here. **Regardless**, it can’t compare to this **Texas-sized** headache I have now. I’ve taken some Aleve, and it’s **working**—all I need now is some well-deserved R&R. **"Your telephone’s the one that helped me wrap the cord around your neck..." —At the Drive-In"**

Well... Today's been a long day. We had to drive home from Indiana. I'll need to be selective about what I write because I could easily take up too much time and space, and I'm exhausted. First, I have to say camp was incredible—even better than I expected. God has been working in my life lately, and it's amazing. I've turned over a new leaf, I suppose. Anyway, back to the start. We arrived at the Twiggs' house Friday evening and stayed until leaving for camp on Monday. Most of our time was spent at the fair, church, a parade, Walmart, and watching movies.

Today is my last day of summer vacation! Waaaaaa! I have a dentist appointment at 9, which I dread, but I’d rather get it over with than reschedule during my surgery rotation. I’m nervous, scared, jittery—basically every synonym for "I really don’t want to go" to school. This will be a whole new challenge for me. As a perfectionist, I thrive on excelling, but starting new things is tough. I hate feeling like a pawn (as I told Cassie: "I’ll be the pawn insisting on moving like a knight") and not knowing what’s ahead.

Arun Shourie discusses how the current Uttar Pradesh governor had warned, as early as 1996, about the potential rise of a so-called 'third Islamic state' in the subcontinent. T.V. Rajeswar, former head of the Intelligence Bureau and now Uttar Pradesh governor, had highlighted this grave threat in a series of articles published in *The Hindustan Times* back in 1996. Shourie raises a pertinent question: Does knowing that Rajeswar—and not others like Mr. Advani—wrote these warnings lend them credibility? Or does it suggest that his repeated assertions brand him as a closet communalist, unfit to remain governor?

Attitude: bored. Mood: indifferent, but looking forward to tonight. It’s been a long, hard day in the trenches today, folks—almost no time to write for you. Still, it’s great to see Tigger (now Akcron) taking the reins and making an appearance while discussing things. Not much to report; yesterday was Shakespeare on the Green—a lovely play, though I had to leave early, which was disappointing. Maybe someday I’ll see a full Shakespeare performance. But I digress. Akcron’s right about the shower issues—it’s awful. Though, watching people endure self-torture can be oddly amusing.

For the past two days, I've been overwhelmed by terrible exhaustion—bone-dead tiredness. Last evening, I went home and slept until my mother called around eight thirty. When I woke, it was dark; I hadn’t turned on the lights, so for a moment, I couldn’t tell the time or date. There was just my mother’s voice in the darkness as I struggled to grasp reality. I wonder why I’m so drained... Lovely weather this morning—drizzling when I arrived. Though in Calcutta, it’s been raining for three days.

Last night was terrible. I discarded the sweater I was knitting after completing only 14 inches. I lost around $10 worth of yarn (at $8 per skein). The stitches multiplied by the armholes, and the mohair kept tangling as I worked, making frogging ineffective. The yarn kept snapping. Unusually, I didn’t even swear—just gloomily unraveled while listening to *Sex and the City* (thanks, library!). Eventually, I gave up and tossed it. At least I learned a lot from this sweater attempt.

Last night in class, we discussed the week’s assigned reading, *Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World* by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter explores "implacement," while the second examines "displacement." Casey argues that modern culture prioritizes time as the central organizing force—evident in phrases like "running out of time" or "saving time." He proposes that centering culture around place could foster a more grounded community. (This is a rough summary—just in case my professor or classmates read this.) So far, this book has truly captivated me.

Whatever they put into freeze pops to create those vibrant colors should come with a warning: may make your life slightly surreal. While laughter is wonderful, one can’t help but wonder if we’d have ended up on that fire escape, sipping beer in the howling wind, had we not eaten them earlier. Stumbling upon a shuttered bar, we paused to flip through an office-supplies catalog that had arrived in the mail. Lucky we did. Who could’ve guessed it held the deals of a lifetime? Certainly not me. Just a few highlights: purchase 36 permanent markers, receive a stunt kite. Buy 30 lever arch files, score a barbecue.

Currently listening to: *The Little Drummer Boy* by Stevan Pasero... and now my post... Senate Republicans—okay, hands up—who watched the 39-hour judicial nominations marathon last week? I know I didn’t. Well, fine, I tuned in briefly. This colossal waste of time was orchestrated by Republicans who, frustrated that Democrats wouldn’t rubber-stamp four of Bush’s controversial nominees, staged a multi-day spectacle to score political points. Never mind that Democrats have already approved 168 of Bush’s judicial picks—no, that’s insufficient for power-hungry Republicans who somehow believe they have a mandate for such theatrics.

This was a great weekend. I enjoyed a lot of god's green leaf, and after a long time, I listened to Nevermore (something I should’ve started much earlier) and read extensively. I finished three books—Bruce Sterling’s *Heavy Weather*, Larry Niven’s *World of Ptavvs*, and Octavia Butler’s *Parable of the Sower*. *Heavy Weather* was an engaging cyberpunk romp through a near-future USA, ravaged by climate change and chaos. While clever, well-paced, and convincing, I didn’t come away with any profound impressions of the story or characters. Both are well-crafted and vivid—it’s a good book, but not a masterpiece.

Because this is the aftermath. The first week back from practicum was a struggle, but only in the second week has the smoke truly begun to clear. Post-practicum trauma was a hidden epidemic now coming to light. I was overwhelmed, but meeting the course coordinator helped me release my burden, preventing another student from enduring such a pedagogically deficient practicum school. Yesterday (Monday), I encountered another distressed classmate determined to warn the next student assigned to her school. I calmed her, suggesting we approach the administrator first.

Things are incredibly busy here at times, but there's always time for stress-relieving activities. I've discovered I'm terrible at 8-ball and ping pong! Rick (the Canuck) beats me regularly—we have a ping pong table in our building's lobby, perfect for quick games. Last night, I joined an 8-ball tournament at the Hot Spot (our rec tent with a popcorn machine, TVs, jukebox, DVD rentals, pool table, dartboard, and ping pong table). I was doing well in my game until I scratched on the eight ball. Still, I had fun—especially with the two Dutch soldiers who joined.

Fall 1974: I was attempting—for what felt like the thirteenth time—to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then, nor am I now, a math person. I hate math. I’m math-phobic. You get the picture. As I struggled to make sense of algebra, the doorbell rang. I set my book aside and answered the door. No one was there. Perfect. I returned to my studies, and just as a glimmer of understanding surfaced in my subconscious, the doorbell rang again. Bam—my breakthrough vanished. I checked the door, and once again, no one was there. Just what a struggling math student needs: an uninvited prankster.

This past week has been utterly exhausting. I spent Tuesday through Thursday relocating to my new classroom. The new space is larger and nearer to my grade-level team—key factors as I dedicate countless hours preparing for the year. Had I known about the move before the school year ended, I would have discarded many unused books and supplies. Sadly, everything came with me. This week was filled with moving, unpacking, and extensive purging. I’m incredibly grateful to my teammate Jill for her help. She was still teaching in my old room this month, yet she and her wonderful students moved nearly my entire classroom for me!

You can't escape it: a part of you will always live in me. Even if I never bore your child, even if we were never married, even if we were never an official pair... I loved you deeply, and to this day, that feeling echoes in my heart. I will forever cherish the few nights we shared, hearts and limbs entwined in a soulful embrace, bathed in the salty darkness of a beachside evening... or a kiss in the rain. Whenever I feel a shard of glass piercing my heart, you will be there—that fragment of you... bleeding the eternal love that once thrived within me... and still endures... For her.

I'm uncomfortable. Investigative reporting feels very wrong to me—or rather, the article I'm working on and its consequences don't sit well with me. Perhaps it's because I lack conviction, unable to fully grasp the passion behind it, the drive to question. I grew up in a country where asking questions was forbidden. They'd shoot you for that. Jail you under internal security acts. I'm unaccustomed to this freedom of speech, to voicing doubts openly. Admittedly, I'm not the easiest person to get along with.

We had an outing yesterday with my colleagues from the bank. We visited Guintubdan in La Carlota—a first for most of us. The trek to the falls took about 30 minutes, leaving us breathless, but we persevered. The water was icy cold, numbing our bodies within moments. We stayed briefly before heading to nearby waterfalls after another half-hour hike. The effort was worth it—the falls were serene, and the scenery truly breathtaking. It felt like becoming one with nature. Soaking in the chilly water was like communing with Mother Earth, the crisp air and water lulling us into tranquility.

Well, I’m sure my sisters are completely drunk. Today was Pride in San Diego, and I know my sisters—when it’s time to drink, it’s time to drink. It’s the one thing I didn’t inherit from the Buenviajes: the desire to drink. There are few occasions when I don’t mind drinking, but they’re very rare. We have a month left before Ed leaves, and I think it’s finally sinking in for him and for all of us. It hit me a long time ago. I just hope Ed will be here for Bailey’s surgery. We’ve been monitoring his swelling, and there’s definitely quite a bit.

On Saturday, we took Connor to Fireman's Park, believing the fireman's Easter egg hunt started at 11 AM. However, it had actually taken place on Friday. Fortunately, I had brought a bag of eggs just in case, so Connor still enjoyed hunting for them in the park. Sunday morning, he woke up thrilled that the Easter Bunny had visited. Nothing compares to seeing the joy on your child's face. After the egg hunt, we attended church. While the Easter Bunny is fun, we ensure our kids understand the holiday's true meaning. This was Megan's first Easter—she looked adorable in her denim dress and stockings!

Friday, November 22, 2002—Woohoo, my boots are at the house! I forgot and had them delivered to my home instead of work, so I have to wait four more hours to get them. Argh! These are the Face boots and Tredair Flame boots. I rock! Somehow, I managed to get a flat tire. Luckily, I'm at work, so the guys will inflate it and check for leaks. If not, they'll change my tire and put on the spare. Thankfully, my spare is full-sized. I may get to buy a new tire tonight—woohoo! Hamad Tire, here I come! I thought I had found another VW.

I know in a previous post I defended parents, almost taking their side, but here’s my change of heart. Parents don’t know anything. They think they understand you completely, even believing they can read your emotions. They can’t. Parents know nothing about us. When I go upstairs after arguing with Nicole about Kelli, like I just did, and they demand to know what’s wrong—how about you just shut up!? I don’t owe you an explanation every time. Here’s the situation: Nicole and Kelli hate each other. Completely.

Music for the day: 94.7 FM. Almost didn’t make it to work on time—there was a massive accident at 14th and Constitution, turning traffic into a nightmare in Virginia. Thankfully, I skillfully maneuvered from the far left lane to the far right and made it onto Route 50. Of course, this means nothing unless you live nearby...so never mind. Just glad to be sitting here instead of stuck in my car. Yesterday, Sara googled me and, lo and behold, found an email I wrote to Ivan Meisel on ESPN.com published online! I had no idea; I didn’t think it was my best argument, but someone disagreed.

What can I say... *Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban* was absolutely brilliant!! I went to see it right after school on Friday—yes, on opening day! (Thanks, Mike, for the ticket.) Daniel Radcliffe, aka Harry Potter, has grown up so fast, and he’s adorable! Matthew too, haha. The movie was fantastic, though I give it 4½ stars because they skipped some key details. Overall, it was great! I didn’t dress up, but I wore a Ravenclaw tie, even though I prefer Gryffindor. Might see it again in two weeks.

Pears and peanut butter attempt #2. This time, I have firm pears and my own jar of peanut butter for dipping, though it's crunchy rather than smooth—I think it makes a noticeable difference. I'm slightly disappointed because I assumed this was a healthy snack, only to discover that per 100g (our jars are much smaller) there are 614 calories! Best not to dwell on it. Just returned from an evening at my old music teacher's house. Yes, I missed her—but I recorded it! Also found out they're airing repeats of series 9 every morning at 9:55. It was lovely seeing my friend, strange but nice.

Some people are quick to connect this dot: The Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe was invited by the State Department to monitor the election. Observers will come from the OSCE's Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights. This marks the first time such a team will attend a U.S. presidential election.  

Meanwhile, a group of congressional Democrats, including four New Yorkers, has petitioned U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan to send international observers to Florida for this year's presidential balloting. I respectfully disagree. Based on available information, the OSCE appears to be here to learn from the U.S. election process, not oversee it—unlike the initial partisan and childish call for U.N. involvement.

My heinous mood has passed. Forgetting to take Prozac until late in the day + an upcoming period = a very sad, tear-prone Kristin. But a surprise visit from my boyfriend + an ice cream sundae + holding his hand after a terrifying dream about machine guns at the news bureau = Kristin feeling better. I don’t have to work this morning—la la la—but I do need to call a man at KMIZ for his rate card. Tonight, I get to see two of my best friends, Amy and Kate (hopefully with time to study in between). Tomorrow, I might reunite with someone I haven’t seen in a while for our WW date.

GOP faces criticism after recruitment efforts at naturalization ceremonies in Jacksonville prompted complaints, leading to their relocation. By Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy, the Jacksonville citizenship ceremony appeared routine, with nearly 200 people becoming new Americans. Before the event concluded on June 29, an immigration official encouraged attendees to visit a voter registration table—a common practice. However, this table stood out: Republican volunteers distributed forms with the party affiliation box pre-checked, automatically enrolling new voters as GOP members. Linda Cross, who attended to witness her husband Dario Cruz’s oath, found the situation highly suspicious.

Our current PL is relocating onsite the day after tomorrow, which is why this change is happening. I’ll be coordinating with two onsite coordinators and eight team members. Currently, I’m occupied with KT plans, as another project with a team of eight will assist us in the upcoming major release. Additionally, a BS7799 security audit is scheduled for Monday at Infosys Chennai. Many details still need fine-tuning at this stage, but I’m hopeful I can manage everything smoothly. Let’s see how it goes. Cheers, Kavitha.

So it’s not really hooky, but I’ve been accumulating sub-days and decided to cash one in today—Wednesday the 10th in Japan (the post-time shows the U.S. date, so it’s technically incorrect)—so I can just relax for a couple of days. Nothing like 48 hours of daydreaming to recharge creatively. I’m fortunate as a foreigner, and my timing worked out well. The illustration part is the icing on the cake. I’d probably complain more if that hadn’t fallen into my lap. I know I’m getting underpaid, though. I’m not blind to that. Getting hungry. Might grab Mexican food at Speak Easy, the ‘American-style’ diner across from the post office in my little prefecture.

I have always prided myself on making everyone who frequents Casa Pescatore as comfortable as possible. I want them to feel at home, just as they would in their own residence. Yesterday, I hope I succeeded. The crowd gathered on Perry Ave with what many considered 'extreme prejudice.' At 4:30 PM, my best friend Eric and his son Nunu arrived with a huge pan of baked ziti. The tables were set, the food I prepared was ready, and the atmosphere was electric. Before I knew it, my best friend from Florida walked through the door, bringing an instant smile to my face. I missed him terribly. The bonus? His wife joined him—she’s expecting, and this is the closest I’ll get to being an uncle. I spoiled her with tray after tray of food and tiramisu.

I liked the idea of that as an offence—perhaps it could've been a way to avoid being burned as a witch. As a non-American blogger, I've hesitated to engage in certain discussions, especially those about flags. But since I started this topic (the subject, not flag-burning), I should probably weigh in. First, I believe outlawing flag-burning is absurd. The instant you grant any symbol automatic reverence and protection, you take a small but crucial step toward totalitarianism. Symbols are fickle—they don’t inherently represent anything; their meaning lies in perception and interpretation.

Prom is tomorrow... I hope it’s going to be fun. That’s all I ask. Rob arrives on May 14th... Yeah, three weeks from today... Oh god, I think I’m giving myself an ulcer just thinking about it. But I’m so excited to see him—scared, yes, but très excited. The Leafs played last night... But since Calgary was playing at the same time and I’m out west... I had to watch the Calgary game, not the Leafs'. Which is fine, I guess... Considering my Leafs lost... And that makes me sad. But Philly’s a good team... So... I still have bragging rights—they went further than the damn Canucks! Today’s a crazy day...

Okay, so I haven’t seen what my blog will look like yet. But this seems like the right place to start. I’m not entirely sure what will unfold here—whether I’ll take to it or not—but since I spend so much time in front of a screen, I might as well put it to good use by sharing the whirlwind of thoughts bouncing around in my head. I was inspired by a blogger (whom I’ve never met), who kept readers engaged with intimate updates about her daily life while also entertaining them...

1. Everyone has a favorite movie or series—mine is the *Evil Dead* franchise (if it wasn’t obvious). I own one of the largest collections of memorabilia from the series.  
2. Can you play an instrument? Bass guitar—and yes, I rock out.  
3. Biggest money-wasting vice? Compulsive DVD purchases or splurging on new tech.  
4. Any phobias, allergies, or compulsions? None, none, and I must arrange my cash from least to greatest.  
5. How much wood could a woodchuck chuck? Because I said so.

Holla, so I saw *Troy* tonight with my family... I wasn’t impressed. I’m too tired to delve into specifics, but it did have potential. However, too much effort went into the set (which was stunning) and not enough into crafting a cohesive tone or theme. It retold the story but wasn’t gripping, and I didn’t gain much from watching it. The character development was weak. The score also fell flat, feeling like a *Gladiator* knock-off. *Gladiator* used a moaning woman’s vocals effectively, complementing its compelling narrative.

Urllink extends a warm welcome to the newest atom/RDF/RSS reader on the scene: Urllink PulpFiction 1.0 from Freshly Squeezed Software. Packed with native app features, it’s worth noting that it isn’t free—a recurring debate online. You can test it for 15 days before deciding to switch back or purchase it for $25. A standout feature is how each post functions as an independent entity, allowing movement, storage, labeling, and deletion. This could greatly benefit news trackers. As expected, it supports OPML import/export.

Today, I miss my sister terribly—it feels strange not having her around, even if she could be a bit irritating (just kidding!). Though she was only here for a week, her presence was truly felt, and I mean that in the best way. Working on the scrapbook from our trip to Tasmania brings back fond memories—so recent, just last week. Perhaps it’s knowing I won’t see her for a while, with her move to Bristol in September. On a deeper level, she was my connection to family back home. How I miss them all. Tomorrow begins a new term. How did the holidays pass so quickly?

Ever have one of those days when you just don’t know... anything? No? Then skip the rest—this won’t make sense to you. For those continuing, here’s an observation: *Sometimes I wish I’d been given the manual.* A well-made manual tells you: what things are for, their functions, how they work, what happens if you press button X or Y, troubleshooting steps, and the contact details of the all-knowing guru who fixes everything—extremely useful. Sadly, I didn’t come with one.

There’s nothing wrong with PCs—if I were a dedicated gamer with time to spare, I’d definitely own a PC for its vast library of games. Yet, aside from a few standout titles, that massive wall of games at CompUSA grows repetitive over time. At first, I’m envious, but then I realize it’s just endless variations of the same formula—first-person shooters, mysteries, strategy games, simulations. The countless iterations of *Age of Empires* become absurd: *AOE* with orcs! *AOE* with spaceships! *AOE* with fuzzy wombats! It’s like those movie trailers that always start with, "In a world...

On my first playthrough, I lost my main character around hour 10 of 20, and I really wished for a save to reload. I’ve since used a third-party mod/save tool to avoid catastrophic failures. The aiming reticle is too small, and the zoom feels underpowered. Despite these flaws, it’s been a blast. I’m not usually a zombie fan, but the mix of strategy, missions, and first-person combat is fantastic. I play whenever possible—just one more mission, one more supply run, or escaping to safety before quitting.

An absolutely fantastic strategy game! Having played every other wargame (European Escalation and ALB), I can confidently say this one stands out. The unit variety is impressive—while I’m unsure of the exact count, there’s a ton! The graphics are stunning, the sound design is excellent, and the gameplay is truly epic. The in-game chat box on the main menu is surprisingly entertaining—no joke. However, if you think this game is "easy" or are new to the genre, expect a steep learning curve. Don’t get discouraged; you’ll lose many units. Just plan ahead, prioritize anti-air, and anti-tank defenses.

I was initially skeptical about this game and hesitant to buy it. The portal gun concept seemed odd despite my love for sci-fi. Boy, was I wrong. The humor and voice acting are phenomenal—just amazing. It’s not cheesy (well, sometimes). Each character has a distinct sense of humor and personality. And the level design? Simply brilliant. By the way, I’ve never played the first Portal game, but I plan to when I have time. I wouldn’t have tried it if not for the sequel.

Yes, this is a nostalgia trip for thirty-somethings who remember (at least in the UK) enduring the ever-irritating Timmy Mallet just for the five-minute *Transformers* cartoon. The iconic voice actors for Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and others return, instantly recognizable. The classic transformation sound remains intact. I downloaded the game and played it briefly, but it was underwhelming. I spent more time trying to log in than actually playing due to a bug. I experienced no performance issues even at launch, and after all these updates, it runs smoothly. In my opinion, this is a genuinely great and enjoyable game, though the format can be slightly frustrating (with the free-roam city repopulating enemies after story progress). I especially loved the 'dual play' segments (featuring Batman + another character), and the flexibility to switch between controller and mouse/keyboard for tank combat was a nice touch. Driving the Batmobile through the city, including during APC chases, becomes incredibly fun once you learn to use the brakes for sharp turns—mastering this makes cruising around truly satisfying!

Damn fine AAA FPS shooter—that's the bottom line. It looks, sounds, and plays great—stellar mechanics, a gripping story, memorable characters, flawless voice acting, and a killer soundtrack. Not for the faint-hearted though—some cutscenes are brutally vivid. But when a game excels overall, flaws stand out, and here's what I noticed:  
- No SLI support—seriously? I had to shelve it until upgrading my GPU, as it ran poorly on my old GTX 590. A solid single-GPU card is a must.  
- Frustratingly, tiny obstacles are often unclimbable.

You can tell by the hours I’ve invested in this game that I love it. This is everything I hoped a tactical shooter from COD would be. But don’t buy it expecting COD, Battlefield, or any other shooter—it’s in a league of its own. I’ve lost count of how often new players complain about dying quickly. Oh no, you got shot in the face and died—like that never happens in real life. Edit: I’ve played this game extensively, spent plenty on it, and it’s one of the best multiplayer experiences out there. Perfect when you’re not in the mood for CS:GO.

I'm two hours in and absolutely loving this game. The gameplay is solid, the art design is stunning, and the music is surprisingly high-quality and fitting. The story and world are engaging, and the puzzles are enjoyable. But the standout feature is the comedy. Whether you're an RPG veteran or new to the genre, you'll appreciate the humor, jokes, and clever references. Fans of *Final Fantasy VII* or *X* in particular shouldn't miss this—I had to pause after two hours just to rest my cheeks from laughing so much. What a delight!

I'm really sorry—I try to support free-to-play games and indie developers, but I didn't enjoy this one. The description seemed perfect for me, but the execution fell flat. I love puzzle and exploration games, yet I found this one unintuitive. Even after checking guides, I simply didn’t enjoy the gameplay. It also lacks a pause button—or if it exists, I never found it. Given the timed sequences, this feels like a major oversight. Additionally, the game feels more like cutscenes than gameplay, leaving me waiting impatiently.

This game... Phew, where to even begin. It was absolutely stunning, from the story to the graphics—I was hooked. The narrative wasn't just a tale; it felt like I *was* that person, unraveling each twist alongside my character. The gameplay was fantastic, and I discovered so much about myself (like my fear of heights, which only surfaced in the ice caverns). My stomach churned the entire time, but I pushed through for Uncle Fred! If you release a DLC or sequel, I'd be the first to buy it and recommend it to everyone. Thank you to everyone involved—you crafted a masterpiece.

Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth is a turn-based strategy game where you develop your civilization toward a specific goal or 'victory.' Unlike previous titles set across Earth's historical eras, this game propels you into the future on a mission to colonize a new planet. What I appreciate most is 2K's innovative approach, introducing fresh mechanics like the affinity system and orbital layer. However, these additions occasionally make the game feel overwhelming. One area for improvement could be enhancing the artwork, particularly the environments during leader interactions.

Great game! Tons of replayability and a very fun zombie survival experience! Definitely in my top 5 zombie games ever. Edit: After 60+ hours, I can confidently say this is one of the better, more 'realistic' zombie games. Designed like a survival horror, you must conserve ammo, treat wounds, and manage infections. The zombies are well-animated and feel natural for a free-to-play title. P.S.: I’d recommend playing with 1 or 2 friends, but the community is super friendly—you can easily make friends via chat or voice comms.

02/07/2014 - It's disappointing that I can't fully recommend this game. From my brief experience, I'd be addicted if not for two major issues:  

1. No Australian servers - A single red bar creates severe lag, putting you at a disadvantage. Even offline training mode stuttered (how does that happen?). Combined with poor ping, it ruins the experience.  

2. Constant artifacting - Menus, backgrounds, and gameplay all glitch excessively. This never happened before with my GPU, even after resetting overclock settings. Stock speeds made no difference.

Very late last night, I finished this. The story isn't particularly deep or compelling, but the storytelling sets it apart. The atmosphere is immersive, and the numerous collectibles do an excellent job of fleshing it out. I learned a lot about Batman's world, so it was disappointing that the game featured so few bosses. Oh well, future titles can address that. The combat offers a fair challenge but leans toward the easier side. Leveling up Batman felt underwhelming. However, upgrading and acquiring gadgets throughout the campaign introduces enjoyable new mechanics. Gaining access to previously unreachable areas creates a satisfying sense of progression.

To the Moon" is no mere game—it's a profound experience and one of the best of my life. Think Telltale's *The Walking Dead* is sad? It doesn't compare to *To the Moon*! Never before has something purely fictional left me so heartbroken yet fulfilled. This masterpiece represents storytelling at its finest, with a soundtrack that’s charming and perfectly complements the narrative. Yes, the controls are a bit clunky and gameplay isn’t its strength, but the story is so compelling that it didn’t matter. The humor is delightful without undermining the emotional depth, and the *Doctor Who* references are a delightful bonus.

Bastion is an outstanding game with a captivating storyline. Set after a calamity, you rebuild the bastion with plenty of choices—what structures to construct, which weapons to wield, and which upgrades or drinks to enhance your abilities. The art style and music are fantastic, proving the apocalypse doesn’t have to be bleak. Best of all, the dynamic narration reacts to your actions. For example, swapping weapons prompts the narrator to comment on your new choice.

I originally bought this game during early development when spacebux was the only currency, and there was no 'tech tree.' Back then, the game was great. All guns were equally overpowered, so balance wasn't an issue—everyone could kill anyone at any time. Plus, you had unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. For a game boasting 'bajillions of guns,' you'd expect more than six weapon slots and three free loadouts before needing to pay. At one point, I had three pages of guns and was brainstorming new ideas because that’s where I found the fun.

This game was a delightful surprise. While rave reviews can often be misleading, they truly captured the fun of this charming little game. It blends a classic 2D platformer with a MOBA in a stylish and unique way. I enjoyed characters I wouldn’t typically favor in other MOBAs. Initially skeptical, I tried a melee tank and was pleasantly surprised, leading me to explore more as they unlocked. The art style and interface are oddly endearing. Now, I even use a character as my avatar and a custom card set wallpaper.

I just started playing, but I love this game. I put on my headphones and lose myself in it for hours. It's been a while since a game captivated me like this. The music sets the mood, the sound effects are spot-on, and the controls are flawless. Every combat feels thrilling, and the system is brilliantly optimized. I had doubts about the naval combat, but annihilating multiple fleets is exhilarating! The only way to lose is failing to retreat—if overwhelmed, regroup and strike back. Thanks, devs, for an amazing experience!

The reboot of the *Devil May Cry* franchise has introduced significant changes to the series, particularly for its protagonist, Dante. While longtime fans may initially resist these alterations, Ninja Theory’s new game demonstrates they’re ultimately for the best. *DmC* offers newcomers the ideal entry point, showcasing the origins of an arrogant, cynical Dante and tracing his evolution toward selflessness. The game crafts a clear narrative arc for this reimagined hero, making him compelling to follow. The story immerses Dante in the corrupt world he once willfully ignored.

Where do I begin with this absolutely beautiful game? Its story is utterly charming, packed with detail, and brimming with happiness, bad puns, annoying dogs, and secrets. It balances seriousness with humor effortlessly. The character design is impeccable, featuring diverse personalities and hidden depths. It stands out among RPGs by allowing a pacifist approach—a rare concept. Drawing inspiration from EarthBound, one of the finest RPGs, its quality is undeniable. Plus, the soundtrack is the best I've heard in years.

I recommend this solely because it's free and may offer a more enjoyable experience for others. Personally, the 'game' did nothing for me. Half the story relies on shock value, but I felt neither shocked nor moved. Perhaps I'm desensitized, or it was too simplistic to evoke a reaction. The other half depicts mental decline, exploring obsession, hallucination, depression, and more. The concept is intriguing, but the 'game' took only 10 minutes to complete—even while absorbing every detail.

Do I even need to explain why *Portal* is amazing? It's a puzzle game that introduces a concept and then steps back. It brilliantly challenges your mind while remaining fun. Though not story-heavy, it spawned one of the most beloved games of 2011. I still play and complete it when bored, returning to witness the birth of a legend—and the legend itself.  

**Gameplay:** *Portal's* mechanics are simple to explain. You use portals strategically, alongside buttons that activate puzzle elements. There are two button types: one you press and another requiring a cube.

If you can overlook the bugs (I encountered only two—one minor, the other annoying—both now resolved, with one fix boosting my FPS from 60-90 to 80-120) and seek a space exploration game, I highly recommend this. Since most reviews focus on specs, here’s mine: i5 6600k (~€200), Radeon RX 480 (~€200), Z170 Pro Gaming (~€150), 16GB DDR4 RAM (~€70). At ~€650, this rig is mid-range but relatively new. Nearly constant 60+ FPS on high settings (VSync enabled). I’m baffled by claims of 20 FPS on overkill setups.

Remember *Age of Mythology*? It’s been ages since an RTS game of that caliber came along. *Divinity: Dragon Commander* comes remarkably close to being my personal favorite. Pair that with a grand strategy mode reminiscent of *Risk*, and it nails the experience. I try not to be biased, but the ability to transform into a dragon—supporting troops, attacking, and managing production—is undeniably thrilling. While I enjoy intricate RTS games like *Civ V*, many overload players with convoluted mechanics, charts, and resource systems.

Undertale combines its elements to create something extraordinary. The retro-style graphics are solid, and the music is pleasant, but together they craft truly beautiful and impactful moments. The script ranges from comedic to dramatic, heartbreaking to hopeful—sometimes simultaneously—while subverting RPG tropes. And that’s without mentioning the world, characters, story, or gameplay... I could write endlessly about it. Instead, I’ll say this: if you like RPGs, play this game. If you enjoy video games, play it. If you have seven free hours in your lifetime, play this game.

I’ve only had this game for a few months, yet in that short time, two DLCs have been released alongside patches that transformed an already great game into an exceptional one. The developers are highly engaged with the community, evident in forums and dev diaries. The mechanics have a steep learning curve, which I’m still mastering, but the strategic depth offers countless ways to achieve goals and capitalize on situations. In my opinion, the game is nearly infinitely replayable. I get completely absorbed in every session, no matter how the playthrough unfolds.

Warframe is an enjoyable game for the first few hours. After that initial fun, you'll notice the gameplay becomes repetitive, with similar combat and enemies. However, the developers actively support the game, releasing frequent updates that introduce sweeping changes, new Warframes, and additional features. It's a solid choice for casual play, though it may not hold your interest long-term unless you enjoy grinding. The best part? It's free, so it's worth trying. If you're seeking a quick gaming fix, give it a shot.

This game is incredibly boring. I purchased it believing it was a PC version of *Katamari Damacy*, a beloved PS2 title. Unfortunately, it falls far short. The gameplay involves absorbing progressively larger objects to grow bigger, but it lacks smoothness and creativity. The levels feel uninspired, and the overall experience is a surreal horror show—not the entertaining kind, but one that leaves you questioning existence. Every "living" creature, from pets to humans, makes me wonder if the developers had a fascination with taxidermy.

Alright. Let me explain a few things. As someone deeply interested in politics, I was intrigued by this game when I first heard about it. I thought, *Wow! A simulator of the road to becoming president—that sounds fun!* Well, it really wasn't. The game starts by forcing you to pick a side: Republican or Democrat, with no independent or third-party option. A little disappointed but still optimistic, I continued to see what I could do. I’ll give the game credit—the character customization, though limited, is fun to experiment with. It’s the only time you can choose whether to wear your head in a campaign. Literally.

Fallout 3's story was superior. Settlements disrupt the narrative, making you resent babysitting them instead of enjoying the story. Some keys are hardcoded and can't be rebound. Bugs are rampant—my Pip-Boy vanished permanently, forcing me to use console commands to restore it. Power armor requires no effort; it's handed to you early, and fusion cores are abundant in shops, diminishing its value compared to earlier games. The story is mediocre, as is most of the game, though it's more stable than Fallout 3. Is it better than Fallout 3? No. New Vegas? No. This title was vastly overhyped for its actual quality.

Undoubtedly my favorite first-person shooter of all time. Run-and-gun rambos need not apply. Recoil and ballistics feel authentic. Rifle rounds to the chest, neck, or head are almost always fatal unless they barely graze you. Bullets drop over distance, and controlled bursts are essential for accuracy. There’s no infinite ammo—reload mid-magazine often, and you’ll end up with pouches of half-empty clips. Sprinting drains stamina, worsening your aim as you gasp for breath. Stabilize your weapon by resting it on surfaces or going prone. Standing shots are less precise.

Let me start by saying I didn’t purchase EU when it first released; I got it on sale with EW included, so I never encountered the issues some people reported. I loved the game—it was challenging early on but rewarding when done right. As for XCOM 2, I adore it. The game runs smoothly on medium settings with my GTX 560 (2GB VRAM). Initially set to high, it was sluggish but still playable; lowering it to medium fixed the issue. I’m not sure if I’m just lucky with game performance, but many negative reviews seem to come from overly entitled players.

World leaders gather to face uncertainty as over 2,000 business and political figures from across the globe arrive in the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). For five days, they will address issues ranging from China's economic influence to Iraq's post-election future. UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki are among the 20+ heads of state attending. Unlike past years, protests against the WEF are expected to be minimal, as anti-globalization activists canceled planned demonstrations. Meanwhile, Porto Alegre, Brazil, will host the rival World Social Forum, coinciding with the WEF's upscale Davos gathering.

The deadline for the Fiat-GM deal approaches, with both companies having until midnight on 1 February to resolve their dispute over a potential takeover. This deadline signifies when Fiat gains the right to sell its car division to GM, as per their 2000 alliance agreement. GM, struggling with losses in Europe, no longer wishes to retain Fiat's unprofitable unit. Reports of stalled negotiations caused Fiat shares to drop 1.2% on Tuesday, following a 4% rise on Monday amid hopes of a settlement. The US automaker is reportedly offering around $2bn (£1.06bn) to exit the agreement. GM claims the deal was invalidated when Fiat sold its finance arm and diluted GM's stake through a capital increase. The 2000 agreement stemmed from a competition between GM and DaimlerChrysler to partner with Fiat.

Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales, has criticised the Iraq War, stating that billions spent on the conflict should have been used to alleviate poverty. Speaking on BBC Radio 4, he denounced the war as a "terrible" waste of resources, a message he will reiterate during his Christmas midnight mass. Both he and the Archbishop of Canterbury have voiced opposition to the war. In his "Thought for the Day" segment, the cardinal lamented that vast sums were spent on warfare rather than lifting people from "dire poverty, malnourishment, and disease." He urged that 2005 become the year to campaign against global poverty.

British stars were denied major Oscars as UK hopes of winning top awards were dashed. Despite three nominations, Mike Leigh's *Vera Drake* missed out on director and screenplay prizes, with no win for star Imelda Staunton. Kate Winslet lost to Hilary Swank for Best Actress, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo fell short in the supporting categories. The UK's Andrea Arnold claimed the short film award for her gritty drama *Wasp*. Arnold, a former children's TV presenter in the 1980s, called the win "totally overwhelming." *Wasp* follows a struggling single mother, triumphing over films by fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

Halloween writer Debra Hill dies. Screenwriter and producer Debra Hill, best known for her work on the 1970s horror classic *Halloween*, has passed away in Los Angeles at age 54. Hill, who battled cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film starring Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter hunted by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, it grossed over $60 million globally—a record for independent cinema then. Hill also partnered with Carpenter on *Escape from New York* and *The Fog*. Born in New Jersey, she started as a production assistant and rose through the ranks to become an assistant and second-unit director before teaming up with Carpenter. Many saw her as a trailblazing woman in film, taking on roles in the '70s typically dominated by men.

Broadband fuels online expression, as fast web access encourages more people to share their thoughts digitally, research suggests. A quarter of broadband users in Britain regularly upload content and maintain personal sites, according to a report by UK think-tank Demos. It found that always-on, high-speed connections are transforming internet usage. Over five million UK households now have broadband, with rapid growth continuing. The Demos report examined broadband's influence on online behavior, revealing that more than half of users log on before breakfast. One in five even admitted to waking at night to browse. Most notably, broadband is empowering users to engage more actively online.

Yukos heads back to US courts as the Russian oil and gas company continues its fight for survival. The firm is being dismantled by Russian authorities to settle a $27bn (£14bn) tax bill. Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the US, aiming to leverage international business law to stop the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas. However, the unit was sold for $9.4bn to state-owned Rosneft after the auction was disrupted. Yukos lawyers argue the auction violated US bankruptcy law. The company and its major shareholders have pledged to pursue any buyers of its assets using all legal means available.

Voters flock to the Blog Awards site as voting begins for the annual Bloggies, honoring the best web blogs—online platforms where individuals share their thoughts. Nominations were announced Sunday, but overwhelming traffic temporarily shut down the official site. Weblogs compete in 30 categories, ranging from top regional blog to best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a monumental year, with a leading US dictionary declaring "blog" the word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, monitors roughly six million blogs, noting over 12,000 new additions daily. According to Pew Internet and American Life, a blog is created every 5.8 seconds, yet fewer than 40% are updated bimonthly.

Chinese dam firm 'defies Beijing'—China Three Gorges Project Corp is refusing to halt construction on one of its massive dams, according to state media. The builder of the Three Gorges Dam continues work on the Xiluodu Dam, reported *Beijing News*. Xiluodu is among 30 large-scale projects suspended due to inadequate environmental reviews. The company may opt to pay a fine instead, the report noted. It has also disregarded stop orders for two other projects: the Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and the Three Gorges Power Supply Plant. Only 22 of the 30 projects flagged by China's environmental agency for lacking impact assessments have complied with shutdown orders.

Man City 0-2 Man Utd: Manchester United narrowed Chelsea's Premiership lead to nine points with a hard-fought victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney converted Gary Neville's near-post cross via a deflection off Richard Dunne to put United ahead. Seven minutes later, Dunne inadvertently volleyed the ball over David James and into his own net. Steve McManaman squandered City's best chance, shooting wide from close range in the first half. United initially appeared unlikely to secure the win required to stay in the title race, as their buildup lacked fluidity. They created only one clear opportunity—a Paul Scholes header over the bar—in the opening 45 minutes.

Wales 'must learn health lessons,' says the new health minister, Dr. Brian Gibbons. He emphasizes the need to learn from England's approach to tackling waiting lists. On his first full day in office following Jane Hutt's dismissal, he acknowledged "big challenges" but maintained that the "essentials" were in place. Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats, however, urged Dr. Gibbons to revise current policies. Ms. Hutt defended her tenure, stating waiting times represented "only 10% of the health agenda."  

Dr. Gibbons, a former GP in Blaengwynfi and AM for Aberavon, noted NHS staff sought stability after "tremendous change and reform." One of Ms. Hutt's major challenges during her five-and-a-half-year term as Wales' first health minister was managing lengthy waiting lists.
