Manchester United's Alex Ferguson praised his players' resilient performance in the 1-0 win at Aston Villa. "That was our toughest away game this season—a fantastic match with end-to-end action and excellent passing," said the Old Trafford boss. "We displayed tremendous character and determination. I knew we wouldn’t lose. Arsenal and Chelsea still have to visit, and Villa might be stronger by then."  

Ferguson also lauded veterans Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who replaced the injured John O’Shea. "Roy brought much-needed composure to midfield—a quality no one else possesses.

A documentary offering a candid look at the life of chart-topping singer George Michael will premiere at this year's Berlin Film Festival. *A Different Story* will screen in the festival's Panorama section, running from 10–20 February. The film explores Michael's career and personal journey, from his Wham! days to recent events. Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on 16 February, joined by director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens. The 93-minute documentary delves into his early years with Wham!, his later career, legal battles with Sony, and his opposition to the Iraq War and American politics.

Downloads enter US singles chart: Digital music downloads are now included in the main US singles chart for the first time. Billboard's Hot 100 chart integrates data from music download sales, previously limited to a separate chart. Green Day's *Boulevard of Broken Dreams* ranks second on Billboard's Pop 100 and leads its digital chart. The UK singles chart will also incorporate download sales later this year. In the US, digital sales already contribute to Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. These will now be combined with physical single sales and airplay data for the updated Hot 100. A second new chart, the Pop 100, merges airplay, digital, and physical sales but restricts airplay data to US radio stations playing chart music.

Anti-spam laws hit spammers hard as the self-proclaimed "spam king" seeks bankruptcy protection. Scott Richter, operator of OptInRealBig.com and sender of billions of junk emails, claims lawsuits forced his company into Chapter 11. OptInRealBig faces multiple legal challenges, including a major case from Microsoft seeking millions in damages. The company states Chapter 11 will help address legal issues while maintaining operations. Ranked as the world's third-largest spammer by Spamhaus, OptInRealBig was sued in December 2003 for violating anti-spam laws. Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer alleged Richter's network sent billions of spam messages through 514 compromised addresses across 35 countries.

Arnesen denies rift with Santini  
Tottenham sporting director Frank Arnesen has dismissed claims that coach Jacques Santini resigned due to a clash of personalities at White Hart Lane. Reports suggested Santini felt undermined by Arnesen's role, but Arnesen refuted this, stating, "It is absolutely untrue. His resignation was solely due to personal reasons. He recently confirmed this to me."  

Arnesen admitted he couldn't clarify the exact issues behind Santini's departure after just 13 games. "Jacques never elaborated, but I trust his decision. We must respect it," he added.

Ireland surged past Scotland, maintaining their Six Nations Grand Slam ambitions with an impressive victory at Murrayfield. Hugo Southwell's try gave the Scots an early 8-0 lead, but scores from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell put the visitors in command by half-time. A third try from wing Denis Hickie and Ronan O'Gara's third penalty, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon Petrie scored a second try for Scotland, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed the win. After two hard-earned away victories, Eddie O'Sullivan's side can now look forward to hosting England at Lansdowne Road in a fortnight. Scotland will aim to give coach Matt Williams his first Six Nations win when Italy visit Edinburgh, but they again struggled to convert pressure into points.

Economic focus for election battle: Britain's economic future will be central to Labour's campaign, Chancellor Gordon Brown has stated. He spoke after cabinet members held their final meeting at No. 10 before the anticipated election announcement. Brown emphasized that voters would acknowledge Labour's role in ensuring stability and growth, pledging its continuation. Meanwhile, the Tories outlined plans to address 'yob culture,' while the Lib Dems elaborated on proposals to replace council tax. Earlier, the Archbishop of Canterbury urged all parties, in an open letter, to avoid exploiting public fears on terrorism, asylum, and crime during the campaign.

Brizzel to race in AAA's in Sheffield  
Ballymena sprinter Paul Brizzel will be among eight of Ireland's European Indoor hopefuls competing in this weekend's AAA Championships. US-based Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll are the only Irish athletes selected for the Europeans who will skip Sheffield. Brizzel will defend his 200m title in the British trials.  

In-form James McIlroy aims to secure his spot in the British team for Madrid by winning the 800m title. McIlroy has excelled on the European circuit recently and ranks among the world's fastest 800m runners this winter. Corkman Mark Carroll confirmed midweek he would join Cragg at the European Championships. Carroll is currently ranked third in the world for 3000m, with Cragg holding the top spot.

England rugby union captain Jason Robinson is aiming for dual-code success against Australia on Saturday. Robinson, a former rugby league international who switched codes in 2000, will lead England at Twickenham at 14:30 GMT. Later at 18:15 GMT, Great Britain's rugby league team faces Australia in the Tri-Nations final. "Beating the Aussies in both games would be incredible, especially for league," said Robinson. England could secure their third autumn international win after victories over Canada and South Africa, while also avenging June's 51-15 loss to the Wallabies. Meanwhile, Great Britain may end a 34-year drought against Australia with a win at Elland Road.

Warning over tsunami aid scam: Net users are urged to avoid a fraudulent website claiming to collect donations for tsunami victims. The site appears credible by mimicking an old version of the official Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC) webpage. However, DEC has no ties to the fake site and has reported it to authorities. This scam joins a growing list exploiting goodwill after the tsunami disaster. The link is spread via a spam email currently in circulation, with the subject line "Urgent Tsunami Earthquake Appeal." The message contains the poor grammar and spelling typical of phishing attempts.

Iraq to invite phone licence bids  
Iraq will invite bids for two telephone licences, aiming to significantly expand nationwide coverage over the next decade. Bids are open to local, Arab, and foreign companies, Iraq's Ministry of Communications stated. The winning firms will collaborate with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC) to install and operate a fixed-line network, offering voice, fax, and internet services. The ministry seeks to raise Iraq's "very low telephone penetration rate from 4.5% to 25% within 10 years" and develop a "dynamic telecommunications sector." Bidding details will be published on the ministry's website on 9 February, with an investor roadshow planned in Amman, Jordan.

More women and older adults are increasingly taking charge of safeguarding home computers against cyber threats, according to a two-year study. The research reveals a yearly 11.2% rise in women purchasing antivirus, anti-spam, and anti-spyware software from 2002 to 2004. Conducted for cybersecurity firm Preventon, the study highlights broader awareness among diverse internet users. Notably, 40% of home security software buyers are retirees, with a three-year average growth of 13.2%. Retired women (53%) outpace men in adopting these tools. The findings challenge stereotypes, reflecting shifting demographics and heightened awareness of risks posed by high-speed broadband connections.

Podcasts mark the rise of DIY radio. An Apple iPod or other digital music player can hold up to 10,000 songs, leaving ample space to fill. Increasingly, iPod owners are using that space for audio content from a diverse range of creators. This trend, called "podcasting," is championed by former MTV host and VJ Adam Curry. The term derives from the iPod, though no iPod is needed to make or enjoy a podcast. Essentially, a podcast is an internet-based radio show, often produced at home with just a microphone, a PC, and editing software. Creators upload their shows online, allowing free downloads for listeners.

Andrea Levy, winner of the Orange Prize, has claimed the Whitbread Novel of the Year Award for her book *Small Island*. She now stands as the favorite to win the overall prize after surpassing Booker Prize winner Alan Hollinghurst’s *The Line of Beauty*. Geraldine McCaughrean secured the Children’s Fiction Award for the third time with *Not the End of the World*. All category winners advance to compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which includes a £25,000 prize. A judging panel featuring Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and writer Joanne Harris will convene on 25 January to determine the overall winner, announced later that evening. Bookmaker William Hill has listed Levy’s novel as the 6/4 favorite.

Yukos will return to a US court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the obscure firm that purchased its primary asset. Yukos plans to sue Baikal and others involved in the $20bn sale of Yuganskneftegas for damages. Its US lawyers will push to freeze Baikal's assets after Russia disregarded a court order blocking the sale. Baikal's background and motives remain unclear. Russian media allege Baikal—which acquired Yuganskneftegas for $9.4bn at a state-backed auction—has strong ties to Surgutneftegas, Russia’s fourth-largest oil producer.

Hearts secured a 2-1 victory over Livingston in their Scottish Cup quarter-final clash, scoring twice in the first 10 minutes. Lee Miller struck within 60 seconds, nodding Jamie McAllister's free-kick over Colin Meldrum. McAllister then doubled the lead, meeting Saul Mikoliunas' cross at the back post. Craig Easton pulled one back controversially, but Hearts held firm. The opener came after Gus Bahoken fouled Miller 35 yards out. McAllister delivered the free-kick, and Miller outjumped the defense to loop his header home. Minutes later, Mikoliunas raced down the right and found McAllister, who headed past Meldrum.

Sun Microsystems has introduced a pay-as-you-go service enabling customers to rent substantial computing power by the hour. The Sun Grid charges users $1 (53p) per hour for processing and storage on Sun-maintained systems. Grid computing, the latest industry buzzword, reflects Sun's belief that computing capacity is as vital as hardware and software. Sun compares this shift to the evolution of electricity, suggesting the system could mature similarly to utilities. "Why build your own grid when you can use ours for a buck an hour?" asked Sun's COO Jonathan Schwartz during a webcast announcing the quarterly network computing event in California.

Jamieson issues warning to bigots  
Scotland's Justice Minister has warned bigoted football fans that she intends to hit them "where it hurts most" by banning them from matches. Cathy Jamieson stated that exclusion orders are among several measures under consideration in the Scottish Executive’s campaign against sectarianism. She commended Celtic and Rangers for their efforts in addressing the issue. However, the minister emphasized that curbing sectarian abuse linked to Old Firm matches remains a priority. Ms. Jamieson spoke ahead of the third-round Scottish Cup clash between the Glasgow clubs at Parkhead on Sunday. The sectarianism long tied to segments of both clubs' support has become a key focus for the Executive. Last week, Ms. Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnell met with supporters' representatives from both clubs to discuss the matter.

Hollywood stars Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth attended the British premiere of *Beyond the Sea* in London's Leicester Square on Thursday. Spacey, 45, wrote, directed, and starred in the film, a tribute to 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. "This is my homage to a remarkable talent," said Spacey, who performs all 18 songs on the soundtrack. Bosworth, 21, plays Darin's wife, Sandra Dee. "I knew nothing about Bobby Darin before this film, but now I'm a huge fan," said Bosworth, accompanied by her British boyfriend, Orlando Bloom.

Leeds v Saracens (Fri)  
Headingley  
Friday, 25 February, 2000 GMT  

The Tykes have recruited Newcastle prop Ed Kalman and Tom McGee from the Borders on loan, while fly-half Craig McMullen joins from Narbonne. Raphaël Ibañez starts at hooker for Saracens in one of four changes. Simon Raiwalui and Ben Russell are also named in the pack, with Kevin Sorrell at outside centre.  

Friday’s game at Headingley was cleared after an early pitch inspection.  

**Leeds:** Balshaw; Rees, Christophers, Bell, Doherty; McMullen, Dickens; McGee, Rawlinson, Gerber; Murphy, Palmer (capt), Morgan, Parks, Popham.  
**Replacements:** Kalman, Regan, Hyde, Rigney, McMillan, Rock, Vickerman.

Home phones face an uncertain future, as the fixed-line telephone in your home could soon become an endangered species. Research by handset maker Nokia reveals that an increasing number of people rely solely on their mobile phones for all calls. The study found that over 45 million people in the UK, Germany, the US, and South Korea now exclusively use mobiles. While some retain fixed-line phones due to lower call charges, most respondents agreed that the future is undoubtedly mobile. The Nokia-sponsored research highlighted distinct usage patterns: home phones were preferred for longer calls, whereas mobile conversations tended to be shorter, often with friends. In the UK, 69% of participants cited cost savings as their reason for using fixed-line phones over mobiles.

Melzer stuns Agassi as second seed Andre Agassi suffered a crushing defeat by Jurgen Melzer in the SAP Open quarter-finals. Agassi struggled against the Austrian's drop shots in San Jose, falling 6-3, 6-1. Defending champion Andy Roddick fought back to defeat Thomas Enqvist 3-6, 7-6 (8-6), 7-5. Meanwhile, unseeded Cyril Saulnier ousted fourth seed Vincent Spadea 6-2, 6-4, and Tommy Haas overcame eighth seed Max Mirnyi 6-7 (2-7), 7-6 (7-3), 6-2. Melzer has now defeated Agassi twice in three meetings. "I executed my game plan perfectly," he said. "Facing Andre is always tough. I aimed to disrupt his rhythm—he makes you cover every inch of the court."

A group of MPs has intensified pressure on Tony Blair regarding House of Lords reform by publishing a detailed blueprint for change. The cross-party group unveiled a draft bill proposing a smaller second chamber with 70% elected members. Since 1999, when 600 hereditary peers lost their seats, MPs and peers have failed to agree on reform. The group believes it can secure support to remove the remaining 92 hereditary peers. The government delayed plans to eliminate them, citing opposition in the Lords. Tony Blair insists consensus on reforms is necessary. Suggestions indicate Labour’s manifesto may propose changes to the Lords’ powers.

Allan Scott remains confident of winning a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships despite a slightly disappointing debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the José M Cagigal Memorial Meeting in Madrid. "It was a learning curve, but I’m still aiming for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride athlete. Felipe Vivancos won the race, equalling the Spanish record, followed by Sweden’s Robert Kronberg and Haiti’s Dudley Dorival. Scott, who won his heat in 7.64secs, ran 0.04secs slower in the final.

A U.S. woman is suing Hewlett Packard (HP), alleging its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a set date. The unnamed Georgia resident claims a chip inside the cartridge falsely signals the printer to refill even when unnecessary. The lawsuit aims to represent all U.S. purchasers of HP inkjet printers since February 2001. HP, the world's leading printer manufacturer, declined to comment. Their cartridges use chip technology to detect low ink levels and prompt replacements. However, the suit alleges these chips also deactivate cartridges prematurely, regardless of remaining ink.

Virgin Radio is set to become the first global station to broadcast via 3G mobile networks, in collaboration with technology firm Sydus. The service will be available on select 2G and high-speed 3G networks. Later this year, listeners can download software from Virgin’s website to access the service.  

James Cridland, Virgin Radio’s Head of New Media, stated: "This positions radio at the forefront of the 3G revolution." Virgin Radio will debut first, followed by its digital counterparts, Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove.  

Cridland added: "This app allows anyone, anywhere to enjoy Virgin Radio with just their phone.

Roxy Music is set to perform at June's Isle of Wight Festival, alongside Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. REM has already been confirmed as headliners for the three-day event, running from 10-12 June. Original members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzanera, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson will take the stage on Saturday night. The band is also recording new material, their first since the 1982 album *Avalon*. Formed in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno, with Manzanera joining later, Roxy Music's first hit was 1972's *Virginia Plain*. Other hits include *Street Life*, *Love Is the Drug*, and their 1981 cover of John Lennon's *Jealous Guy*.

Captains lining up for the aid match include Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll, one of four Six Nations skippers selected for the Northern Hemisphere squad in the IRB Rugby Aid match on 5 March. France's Fabien Pelous, Scotland's Gordon Bullock, and Italy's Marco Bortolami also feature. Sir Clive Woodward will coach the Northern team against Rod MacQueen's Southern Hemisphere side in a tsunami fundraiser at Twickenham. 'I'm excited to work with such exceptional players,' he said. The match offers Woodward a chance to evaluate options before announcing his British and Irish Lions squad for their summer tour of New Zealand. 'It promises to be a thrilling spectacle,' he added.

Spirit Awards Hail *Sideways*"  

The comedy *Sideways* dominated this year's Independent Spirit Awards, winning all six categories for which it was nominated. It claimed Best Film, while Alexander Payne earned Best Director and Best Screenplay alongside writing partner Jim Taylor. The film also secured acting honors for stars Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen. *Sideways* is poised for success at Sunday's Oscars, with five nominations.  

Now in their 20th year, the awards recognize films produced outside the traditional studio system and are traditionally held the day before the Oscars. Other winners included Catalina Sandino Moreno, who won Best Actress for her role as a drug smuggler in the Colombian drama *Maria Full of Grace*. Moreno is also an Oscar nominee for Best Actress. Joshua Marston received the Best First Screenplay award for *Maria Full of Grace*.

Prince was crowned the 'top music earner' of 2004, surpassing stars like Madonna and Elton John in *Rolling Stone*'s annual list. He earned $56.5 million (£30.4m) from concerts, album sales, and publishing, thanks to his *Musicology* tour and album. Madonna secured second place with $54.9 million (£29.5m) from her *Re-Invention* tour. Simon & Garfunkel ranked 10th, earning $24.9 million (£13.4m) from their comeback tour. "Prince reclaimed the spotlight after years away," the magazine noted. His 2004 tour grossed $90.3 million (£48.5m), and *Musicology* sold 1.9 million copies.

Irish band U2 were honored at France's prestigious NRJ Music Awards but lost to boy band Blue for the International Group Award. U2 received a special achievement prize, while Maroon 5 won Best New International Artist and Best International Song for *This Love*. Over five million radio listeners voted in the awards. Usher and Avril Lavigne claimed the International Male and Female prizes, respectively. Accepting his band's award from Naomi Campbell in Cannes, U2's Bono said in French: "I'm not from this country, but I'll confess—it's on the Côte d'Azur where I feel at home.

Walmart fights back at critics as two major U.S. companies launch advertising campaigns to clarify their products and corporate conduct. The world's largest retailer placed over 100 full-page ads in national newspapers, addressing criticism over pay, benefits, and promotions. Meanwhile, pharmaceutical giant Eli Lilly plans a campaign countering "false" claims about its drug Prozac. Walmart initiated the effort with ads in publications like *The Wall Street Journal*, featuring an open letter from CEO Lee Scott urging the public to hear the "unfiltered truth." He stated, "Many 'urban myths' circulate about Walmart, but facts remain facts.

At a glance: The UK's opposition Conservatives have unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here's an overview of the proposal: Individuals moving to Britain from outside the EU who intend to stay six months or longer—and are from high-TB countries—would require a chest X-ray and further tests if necessary. Those from outside the European Union planning to stay a year or more would need a full medical examination, including screening for tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive TB test would result in automatic visa rejection, while other conditions would be assessed individually.

Paris Promise Raises Welsh Hopes. Has there ever been a better Six Nations match than Saturday's epic in Paris? And can Wales' revival continue all the way to a first Grand Slam since 1978? These questions captivate not just Welsh supporters but rugby fans worldwide after a scintillating display. Welsh legend Mervyn Davies, part of two Grand Slam-winning sides in the 1970s, hailed it as "one of the great performances of the past three decades." Martyn Williams, Wales' two-try scorer, called it "one of the most surreal games I've ever played in." A crestfallen French coach, Bernard Laporte, simply noted: "There was a French half and a Welsh half.

Doves soar to UK album summit. Manchester rock band Doves have debuted at number one on the UK album chart with their new release, *Some Cities*. The trio replaces flamboyant US act Scissor Sisters at the top. The album follows their single *Black and White Town*, which peaked at number six. R&B star Nelly claims the new number one single with *Over and Over*, featuring Tim McGraw. Girls Aloud, Akon, and Kaiser Chiefs all have new top-ten singles, alongside Futureheads and Usher. The latest Elvis Presley re-release, *(Marie's the Name) His Latest Flame*, enters at number three, just ahead of Girls Aloud's *Wake Me Up*. Hip-hop artist Akon's *Locked Up* holds number five, while Leeds band Kaiser Chiefs secure their second chart hit at number six with *Oh My God*.

Davies favors Gloucester future. Wales hooker Mefin Davies is likely to remain with English side Gloucester despite reported interest from the Neath-Swansea Ospreys. BBC Wales understands the Ospreys are keen on the 32-year-old, but he prefers to stay put. Davies, a standout in Saturday's RBS Six Nations win over England, is on a one-year contract at Kingsholm. However, the hooker has proven his value to the Zurich Premiership side and is expected to secure a new deal next season. The summer collapse of the Celtic Warriors left Davies without a team, forcing him to accept a semi-professional contract with Neath RFC. While he played for the Ospreys at Wales' request, he admitted feeling frustrated with his treatment before joining Gloucester.

Cabinet anger at Brown's cash raid: Ministers are unhappy about plans to use Whitehall funds to curb council tax hikes, Local Government Minister Nick Raynsford has acknowledged. Chancellor Gordon Brown redirected £512m from central to local budgets in his pre-budget report. Raynsford admitted to holding "frank discussions" with colleagues but stressed that councils must maintain services without significant tax increases. The funding is part of a £1bn package to limit next year's council tax rises below 5%—a crucial move in an anticipated election year. Raynsford noted that nearly all government departments benefit from well-managed local authorities.

An Israeli club is turning to Africa, with four African players—including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro—set to play for Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin in the UEFA Cup. Bnei Sakhnin, the first Arab team in European competition, will face English Premier League side Newcastle United in the first round. Murambadoro, who shone at the Africa Cup of Nations in Tunisia, helped the club defeat Albania's Partizani Tirana 6-1 in the previous round. After a short spell with South African club Hellenic, he recently moved to Israel. Based near Haifa, Sakhnin won last season's Israeli Cup and champions peace and cooperation within Israel.

New drink limit 'would cut toll'—more lives than previously thought could be saved by reducing drink-drive limits by a third, a report reveals. University College London research suggests lowering the limit from 80mg to 50mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood would save 65 lives annually. The findings, published by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety, coincide with MPs voting on the government's Road Safety Bill. The bill revises speeding fines but leaves the drink-drive limit unchanged.  

Transport expert Professor Richard Allsop's research indicates this change would also prevent 230 serious injuries on UK roads compared to 2003, saving £119m yearly. A 1998 Department of Transport estimate had projected only 50 lives saved annually.

This paper introduces a millimeter-scale CMOS 64×64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1×1 μm² diode detects energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, while the array design offers a large detection area of 512×512 μm². Rather than sensing voltage drop from radiation, the system measures pulse width—the time for voltage to return to baseline—eliminating the need for power-hungry, bulky ADCs. A prototype ASIC, fabricated in TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS, consumes an average static power of 0.535 mW at 1.2 V. The system’s functionality is successfully validated in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam.

Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been shown to mitigate the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, assuming AVs would willingly accept external control by a central authority is unrealistic. We propose a joint routing and pricing scheme to incentivize AVs toward system-optimal routing by offering toll savings, while user-equilibrium-seeking AVs and human-driven vehicles (HVs) face congestion charges. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization: dynamic tolls are optimized at the upper level, while the lower level employs a simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model for mixed AV-HV fleets.

Optomechanics and electromechanics now enable macroscopic mechanical oscillators to be prepared in quantum ground states, quadrature squeezed states, and entangled states of motion. Beyond pushing larger objects into quantum regimes, this advancement has spurred ideas for using mechanical oscillators in quantum information processing, communication, and ultra-precise force sensing beyond the standard quantum limit. However, the predominantly linear interaction between motion and light or electricity restricts access to richer quantum states like cat states or energy squeezed states. Early proposals suggested overcoming this limitation through strong quadratic coupling of motion to light. While experiments have demonstrated quadratically coupled optomechanical systems, nonclassical states of motion remain elusive.

Online reviews offer product evaluations to guide customer decisions. However, these evaluations can be manipulated through fake reviews ("spams") by professional spammers, who continuously refine deceptive strategies to evade detection. Spamming tactics are difficult to track, as they evolve rapidly, vary by spammer and product, and often remain undiscovered. Moreover, most existing detectors prioritize accuracy, which does not fully align with preserving evaluation trustworthiness. To tackle these challenges, we model a minimax game where spammers and detectors compete based on practical objectives beyond mere detection accuracy. Nash equilibria yield stable detectors that remain effective against diverse spamming strategies.

We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra-high-fidelity population transfer in a 3-level quantum system with lambda configuration. To ensure high fidelity, we employ the Lewis-Riesenfeld method to derive a family of solutions enabling exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the LR invariant. Within this family, we identify a tracking solution with a single parameter to simultaneously control transfer fidelity, excited-state population, and robustness. We quantify robustness as the minimum percentile deviation in pulse areas at which infidelity exceeds \(10^{-4}\). Our shaped pulses demonstrate superior robustness compared to Gaussian and adiabatically optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.

In this paper, we examine the landscape of the population negative log-likelihood function for Gaussian mixture models with an arbitrary number of components. Due to nonconvexity, multiple local minima exist that are not globally optimal, even in well-separated mixtures. We demonstrate that all local minima share a common structural form, partially identifying the true component centers. Specifically, each local minimum involves either fitting multiple Gaussians to a single true component or fitting one Gaussian to multiple true components. Our findings hold under a separation condition for the true components and remain valid even when the component count is misspecified. For three-component Gaussian mixtures, we derive sharper results based on the separation scaling.

We examine the relationship between two constructions of the mirror partner for the Calabi-Yau orbifold. This orbifold is defined as a quotient by a suitable subgroup \( G \) of the phase symmetries of the hypersurface \( X_m \) in weighted projective space, given by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial \( W_m \). The first, Berglund-Hübsch-Krawitz (BHK) construction, employs another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface \( X_{m^t} \) by a dual group \( G^t \). The second, Batyrev construction, defines the mirror as a hypersurface in a toric variety associated with the dual reflexive polytope of the original Calabi-Yau orbifold. We provide a simple proof of the equivalence of these two constructions.

In this work, we generalize the study of human gait by building upon existing models in the literature, such as those by Keller and Kockshenev. Our hybrid model combines metabolic energy minimization during locomotion with a non-linear description of the mass center's libration to reproduce walk-run transition behavior. Experimental results across different speed regimes show that the trajectory perimeter of the mass center is crucial for quantifying this dynamic. The experimental procedure was conducted in collaboration with the biomedical engineering research group and laboratories at Manuela Beltrán University in Bogotá, Colombia.

We introduce a new mixed-variable symplectic (MVS) integrator for planetary systems, designed to fully resolve close encounters. The method employs time regularization to preserve symplectic stability while dynamically reducing the step size during planetary encounters. Using a high-order MVS scheme, it integrates efficiently with large time steps outside close encounters. This algorithm accurately resolves near-collisions (within a fraction of a physical radius) while maintaining the same time step as in weakly perturbed systems like the solar system. We validate its long-term performance on six super-Earths undergoing strong scattering over 50 kyr. Compared to hybrid methods like Mercury, our approach achieves superior energy conservation at comparable computational cost.

Entanglement is a fundamental resource for quantum information processing. A common tool for detecting entanglement is the entanglement witness, where measuring the witness operator yields positive results for all separable states and may be negative for certain entangled states. In practice, constructing efficient witnesses for general multipartite entangled states is highly challenging due to the exponential growth of Hilbert-space dimension with system size. For $n$-partite Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ)-like states, the most robust witness requires $n+1$ local measurement settings and tolerates up to $1/2$ white noise. In contrast, the most efficient witness for GHZ-like states needs only two measurement settings and tolerates up to $1/3$ white noise.

Within general relativity, the unique stationary solution for an isolated black hole is the Kerr spacetime, characterized by a distinct multipolar structure determined solely by its mass and spin. We present a general method to extract multipole moments from arbitrary stationary spacetimes and apply it to a broad class of horizonless microstate geometries. These geometries can violate the axial and equatorial symmetry of the Kerr metric, exhibiting a far richer multipolar structure that offers a pathway to phenomenologically constrain fuzzball models. Numerical evidence suggests all multipole moments are typically larger (in absolute value) than those of a Kerr black hole with identical mass and spin. Current measurements of black-hole candidates' quadrupole moments impose only weak constraints on fuzzballs, whereas future gravitational-wave observations of extreme mass-ratio inspirals with LISA will enhance these bounds significantly.

Reasoning about evolving graphs is a challenging task across domains like bioinformatics, physics, and social networks. We examine a scenario where edges represent either transient interactions (e.g., messaging) or persistent connections (e.g., friendships). Typically, long-term edges are manually defined, which can be costly and suboptimal for applications. To address this, we introduce a model combining temporal point processes with variational autoencoders that learns temporal attention between nodes by observing their interactions. Since temporal attention governs feature propagation between nodes, learning this component from interaction dynamics offers greater flexibility while circumventing the limitations of human-specified edges.

"We report observations of thermally driven transverse vibrations in a photonic crystal waveguide (pcw). The pcw comprises two parallel nanobeams separated by a 240 nm vacuum gap. Models are developed and validated to transduce beam motion into phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe propagating in a guided mode (gm) of the pcw, both far from and near the dielectric band edge. Since our pcw is designed for near-field atom trapping, this work establishes a framework for assessing potential thermal motion effects on optical atomic traps near pcw surfaces. Long-term objectives include achieving strong atom-mediated coupling between individual phonons and single photons in the pcw’s gms, enabling quantum-level optomechanics with atoms, photons, and phonons.

We establish natural splittings for the values of global Mackey functors at orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups. In particular, the restriction homomorphisms between these groups of adjacent dimensions are naturally split epimorphisms. The interest in these splittings arises from equivariant stable homotopy theory. The equivariant stable homotopy groups of every global spectrum form a global Mackey functor, so the splittings imply that certain long exact sequences decompose into short exact sequences. For the real and complex global Thom spectra $\mathbf{MO}$ and $\mathbf{MU}$, the splittings ensure the regularity of various Euler classes associated with the tautological representations of $O(n)$ and $U(n)$.

Baryonic feedback effects suppress the weak lensing angular power spectrum on small scales. The uncertain shape and amplitude of this suppression pose significant challenges for future cosmological weak lensing surveys like *Euclid* or *LSST*. In this first paper of a two-part series, we use simulations to construct a *Euclid*-like tomographic mock dataset for the cosmic shear power spectrum and its covariance matrix, both corrected for baryonic effects using the baryonification method from Schneider et al. (2019). Additionally, we develop an emulator to rapidly predict baryonic power suppression, enabling a likelihood inference analysis for a standard ΛCDM cosmology with both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.

Spontaneous conversations in real-world settings, like those in child-centered recordings, are among the most challenging audio files to process. However, developing speech processing models capable of handling such diverse conditions is highly valuable for language acquisition studies. Researchers can analyze the quantity and quality of speech children hear and produce, as well as enable early diagnosis and measure remediation effects. In this paper, we introduce an open-source neural network designed to classify audio segments into vocalizations from the child wearing the recorder, other children, adult male speech, and adult female speech. For this purpose, we compiled diverse child-centered corpora totaling 260 hours of recordings across 10 languages.

Density-based clustering relies on linking groups to specific features of the probability distribution underlying the data. By referencing the true, yet unknown, population structure, the clustering problem can be framed in a standard inferential setting. Here, the ideal population clustering is defined as the partition induced by the true density function. The nonparametric version, called modal clustering, associates groups with the domains of attraction of the density modes. Operationally, this requires a nonparametric density estimate, and selecting the right amount of smoothing—which affects the density's shape and modal structure—is key to determining the final partition. In this work, we examine density estimation for modal clustering from an asymptotic perspective.

The tails of diboson production at the LHC are sensitive to interference between the Standard Model and higher-dimension operators, which parameterize the effects of heavy new physics. However, helicity selection rules for diboson scattering amplitudes obstruct the naïve interference contributions of dimension-six operators, causing the leading correction to the total diboson rate to cancel. In this scenario, precise measurements of azimuthal decay angles "resurrect" the interference, restoring sensitivity to the "non-interfering" operators. We analyze these signatures in detail and find that EFT uncertainties from higher-dimensional operators are uniquely suppressed by constructing an asymmetry variable generated exclusively by these non-interfering operators, relegating the effects of interfering higher-dimensional operators to the same level as statistical uncertainties.

Causal inference from observational data is a key objective in health and social science research. Yet, academic statistics has traditionally viewed causal analyses with skepticism. The emergence of "data science" offers a unique opportunity to redefine data analysis, seamlessly integrating causal inference from observational data. Following prior work, we categorize data science contributions into three tasks: description, prediction, and counterfactual prediction (encompassing causal inference). A clear classification of these tasks is essential to address the data, assumptions, and methods needed for each. We contend that overlooking the role of domain expertise in data analysis fuels widespread misconceptions about data science.

The weak gravity conjecture (WGC) requires superextremal particles in any consistent quantum theory of gravity. Conventionally, these particles ensure extremal black holes are unstable or marginally stable, but the consequences of violating this condition remain unclear. This note demonstrates that, for a generic Einstein quantum theory of gravity in AdS, exact stability of extremal black branes conflicts with rigorously proven quantum information theorems about entanglement entropy. Resolving this tension yields a nonperturbative version of the WGC, reducing to the standard form at weak coupling. The argument is general, relying neither on supersymmetry nor a specific UV completion, and assumes only the validity of Einsteinian gravity, effective field theory, and holography.

Understanding how strongly correlated two-dimensional (2D) systems can produce unconventional superconductivity with high critical temperatures remains a key challenge in condensed matter physics. Ultracold 2D Fermi gases have become ideal model systems to investigate the interplay between strong correlations and reduced dimensionality, yet direct evidence of superfluidity has been lacking. Here, we observe superfluidity in an ultracold 2D Fermi gas by moving a periodic potential through the system and detecting no dissipation below a critical velocity v$_{\rm c}$. We measure v$_{\rm c}$ across interaction strengths, finding a peak in the crossover between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity. This result confirms ultracold Fermi gases as a versatile platform for exploring strongly correlated superfluids in reduced dimensions.

Ordinary differential equations (ODEs) are mathematical models widely used in fields like climatology, bioinformatics, and chemical engineering due to their intuitive modeling appeal. However, the frequent lack of analytic solutions complicates parameter estimation, particularly for models with many variables. This paper introduces a fast and accurate Bayesian ODE parameter estimation algorithm, even for high-dimensional models. The method approximates the ODE using a state-space model derived from numerical solver equations, enabling rapid estimation by bypassing full numerical solutions in likelihood computations. The posterior is obtained via variational Bayes, specifically the approximate Riemannian conjugate gradient method (Honkela et al.).

We investigate the transport properties and superconducting proximity effect in nsn junctions composed of a time-reversal symmetry broken Weyl semimetal (WSM) coupled to an $s$-wave superconductor. Our results show that the differential conductance and induced pairing amplitudes are highly sensitive to the angle between the junction direction in real space and the axis separating the Weyl nodes in momentum space. We analyze the impact of a chiral chemical potential—the electron population imbalance between Weyl nodes of opposite chirality—on the junction's transport behavior. Notably, we detect a net spin polarization of Cooper pairs generated via Andreev reflection in both WSM regions. This polarization is opposite in the two regions and strongly dependent on the chirality imbalance and excitation energy.

Metal ion implantation into ceramics has proven to be an effective and precise method for modifying surface electrical conductivity, with diverse applications. Notably, it enables controlled voltage grading across high-voltage insulators, enhancing their maximum operational voltage without surface flashover. However, a key concern is the long-term stability of implantation-induced conductivity, particularly when using oxidation-prone metal species. This study investigates the durability of surface conductivity in titanium-implanted alumina. Findings reveal an initial 40% conductivity drop within weeks post-implantation, followed by a gradual decline of approximately 10% over the subsequent year.

We present a novel Skyrme-like conserved current in the effective theory of pions and vector mesons, grounded in hidden local symmetry. The associated charge matches the skyrmion charge for smooth configurations. Furthermore, singular configurations arise, identifiable as \( n_f=1 \) baryons charged under this symmetry. Here, vector mesons act as Chern-Simons fields on the quantum Hall droplet forming the baryon. We argue this current accurately represents the low-energy baryon current, unifying both baryon types and enabling their natural continuous transformation. Additionally, Chern-Simons dualities on the droplet emerge from a Seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons.

Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in Josephson junctions provides a fascinating platform to merge anomalous Hall and Josephson physics in a single device. We theoretically examine how the interplay of these effects influences the transport properties of superconductor/ferromagnetic insulator/superconductor junctions. Skew tunneling of Cooper pairs through the spin-active interface generates significant transverse Hall supercurrents, termed anomalous Josephson Hall effect currents. We extend the Furusaki-Tsukada formula, originally developed to quantify conventional Josephson currents, to compute transverse components and show their amplitudes are highly tunable via spin-orbit coupling strengths or the superconducting phase difference. As a distinct spectroscopic signature of Josephson junctions, localized subgap bound states emerge near the interface.

Following the Monte Carlo experiments in Jiménez (J. Turbul. 2020), which suggest dipoles are as crucial to decaying 2D turbulence dynamics as individual vortex cores, we find the kinetic energy is carried by elongated streams formed from dipole concatenation. Vortices split into small, fast-moving cores and larger, slow-moving ones, the latter appearing "frozen" in a slowly evolving "crystal." Their kinematics differ significantly, with only the former being self-similar. The slow component dominates the flow's kinetic energy, forming dipoles and streams. Mechanisms for its growth are examined.

Continuous-time quantum walks are a powerful framework for designing quantum algorithms. Typically, the runtime of such algorithms is determined by the quantum hitting time—the duration needed for the walk to locate a target vertex with high probability. This article presents enhanced upper bounds for quantum hitting times, applicable to various CTQW-based algorithms. Specifically, we refine the hitting time for the glued-trees problem, reducing it from \(o(n^5)\) to \(o(n^2\log n)\). Additionally, our approach exponentially improves the precision dependence in the CTQW-based algorithm by Chakraborty et al. for finding marked nodes in ergodic, reversible Markov chains.

Extreme mass ratio inspirals (EMRIs) can be classified as dry or wet EMRIs based on their formation mechanisms. Dry (or "loss-cone") EMRIs, previously considered the primary EMRI sources for the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna, result from multi-body scattering in nuclear star clusters and gravitational capture. In this letter, we highlight an alternative formation channel: wet EMRIs facilitated by accretion flows around galactic-center massive black holes (MBHs). Here, the accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes on inclined orbits, driving their migration toward the MBH—dramatically boosting EMRI formation rates in such galaxies.

When a new user signs up on a website, we typically lack information about them—no interactions with items, no user profile, and no social connections. Despite this, we expect recommender systems to engage users immediately, encouraging them to stay and become active. This challenge, known as the new user cold-start problem, is critical for a company's growth and sustainability. Existing solutions either demand extra user effort (e.g., interviews) or rely on side information like demographics or social ties [10]. However, users may resist interviews, and such side data is often unavailable for cold-start scenarios.

Deep learning has solved many challenges beyond the reach of heuristic algorithms. It has also proven effective in wireless communications, despite existing radio systems being well-understood with optimal algorithms for many tasks. While learning individual receiver components has yielded some improvements, jointly optimizing the entire receiver is more promising. However, this often leads to complex nonlinear problems with impractical optimal solutions. To address this, we propose deeprx, a fully convolutional neural network that processes the entire receiver pipeline—from frequency-domain signals to uncoded bits—in a 5G-compliant manner. We enhance channel estimation accuracy by carefully structuring the CNN's input using both data and pilot symbols.

Mutation-based fuzzing typically starts with a set of non-crashing seed inputs (a corpus) to generate new inputs through mutation. A corpus often contains thousands of similar inputs, and this lack of diversity can waste fuzzing effort through exhaustive mutation. To address this, fuzzers include distillation tools (e.g., afl-cmin) that select the smallest seed subset triggering the same instrumentation data as the full corpus. Minimizing seed count and cumulative size is believed to improve fuzzing efficiency, which we examine systematically. We present results from 34+ CPU-years of fuzzing with five distillation approaches to assess their impact on bug discovery in real-world software.

In this paper, we examine multi-agent discrete-event systems under partial observation. The agents can be grouped such that each group shares isomorphic state transition structures, allowing them to be relabeled into a common template. Using this template, we design a scalable supervisor whose state size and computational cost remain constant regardless of the number of agents. This scalable supervisor, even under partial observation, requires no recomputation when agents are added or removed. We extend prior results by establishing sufficient conditions for safety and maximal permissiveness of the least restrictive scalable supervisor at the template level. An example demonstrates the proposed supervisory synthesis approach.

Electric network frequency (ENF) fluctuations serve as a powerful tool in multimedia forensics. An efficient ENF estimation method is proposed, utilizing temporal windowing based on the filter-bank Capon spectral estimator. Leveraging the Toeplitz structure of the covariance matrix, a Gohberg-Semencul factorization is employed. Additionally, this approach introduces, for the first time in ENF analysis, a non-rectangular temporal window prior to spectral estimation. Krylov matrices enable fast matrix inversion. The proposed method surpasses state-of-the-art techniques in ENF estimation, particularly with 1-second power recordings. For speech recordings, it delivers exceptional accuracy and computational efficiency.

The **direpack** package introduces a collection of modern statistical dimension reduction techniques into Python as a unified, consistent toolkit. The included methods fall into three categories: projection pursuit, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust M-estimators. Additionally, regularized regression estimators based on these techniques are provided, spanning from principal component regression to sparse partial robust M-regression. The package also offers classical and robust preprocessing utilities, such as generalized spatial signs, along with dedicated plotting and cross-validation tools. Designed to align with the scikit-learn API, **direpack** ensures seamless integration into statistical and machine learning pipelines within that framework.

The nonlinear fluorescence emission has been widely used for high-resolution optical imaging. Here, we investigated the fluorescence saturation effect in nitrogen vacancy defects in diamond. Fluorescence reduction was observed under high-power laser excitation, enhancing emission nonlinearity and altering the spatial frequency distribution of the image. A differential excitation protocol was employed to extract high spatial frequency information. By modulating the laser power, imaging resolution improved by approximately 1.6 times compared to confocal microscopy. Given the simplicity of the setup and data processing, this method shows promise for enhancing spatial resolution in sensing and biological labeling with solid-state defects.

When random effects are correlated with sample design variables, standard methods using individual survey weights (inversely proportional to unit inclusion probabilities) in pseudo-likelihood estimation fail to yield asymptotically unbiased inference. We propose a weight-exponentiated formulation for the random effects distribution that ensures unbiased hyperparameter estimation. Our approach is compared with frequentist methods relying on numerical integration, demonstrating that only the Bayesian method achieves both design-unbiased estimation and consistency with the population distribution. Simulations and a business establishment survey application highlight our method's versatility across modeling frameworks and sampling designs. This work culminates recent advances merging traditional survey estimation with Bayesian modeling, bridging two distinct yet rich statistical domains.

Low-symmetry 2D materials—such as ReS₂ and ReSe₂ monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, group-IV monochalcogenide monolayers, and borophene—exhibit more intricate atomistic structures than the honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. Their reduced symmetries lead to inhomogeneous electron, optical, valley, and spin responses, along with novel properties like ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, large nonlinear optical effects, photogalvanic effects, and superconductivity. Unique electronic topological features, nonlinear elastic behaviors, and structural phase transitions also arise from low symmetry. The "Beyond Graphene: Low-Symmetry and Anisotropic 2D Materials" special topic showcases cutting-edge experimental and theoretical research on these materials.

Orientational dynamics in the isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematic polymer with mesogenic and functional side groups were investigated using Kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy. For the first time, it was observed that in a mesogenic polymer, unlike low-molecular-weight mesogens, the relaxation of electric birefringence above the nematic-isotropic transition temperature can be described by multiple exponential processes, with two being predominant. These primary processes alternate within a temperature range of approximately fifty degrees. Dielectric spectroscopy further revealed two distinct orientational relaxation mechanisms: one arising from rotation of the side mesogenic groups and the other linked to main chain segment motion.

Deep hashing methods demonstrate strong retrieval accuracy and efficiency for large-scale image retrieval. Optimizing discrete hash bits remains a key focus in these methods. A common approach involves using activation functions like $\operatorname{sigmoid}(\cdot)$ or $\operatorname{tanh}(\cdot)$ and minimizing quantization loss to approximate discrete values. However, this strategy may trap hash bits in incorrect saturated regions of activation functions without recovery. We term this issue the "dead bits problem (dbp)." Additionally, existing quantization loss exacerbates dbp. To address this, we introduce a simple yet effective gradient amplifier applied before activation functions to mitigate dbp.

We investigate the phenomenology of a hypercharge-zero SU(2) triplet scalar, motivated by two-step electroweak symmetry-breaking. We examine scenarios where the triplet is either stable (contributing to dark matter) or decays via Higgs mixing. The stable case is constrained by LHC disappearing-track searches and direct detection experiments, while the decaying scenario faces limits from multilepton collider searches. Our analysis shows that a two-step electroweak phase transition with a stable triplet and negative quadratic term is excluded by direct detection. An unstable triplet with mass below $230\ \mathrm{GeV}$ is ruled out at $95\%$ confidence.

This paper demonstrates that the eccentric debris rings around Fomalhaut and HD 202628 are narrower than predicted by the standard eccentric planet perturbation model (often termed "pericenter glow"). The model assumes an initially circular, narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis \(a\), whose eccentricity rises to \(e_f\) due to secular perturbations from an eccentric planet after gas disc dispersal, producing a belt of width \(2ae_f\). A slight adjustment to this scenario allows for narrower belts if planetesimals are initially eccentric, possibly due to earlier planet perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary phase. Alternatively, primordial eccentricity could stem from disc instabilities, independent of planetary influence.

An electron is typically considered to possess a single form of kinetic energy, but could it exhibit additional types due to its spin, charge, or interactions with other electrons? In one dimension (1D), the physics of interacting electrons is well described at low energies by the Tomonaga-Luttinger liquid (TLL) model, yet experimental observations beyond this linear regime remain scarce. Here, we present measurements of many-body modes in 1D gated wires using tunneling spectroscopy. We detect two distinct Fermi seas at high energies, linked to spin and charge excitations, alongside the appearance of three additional 1D "replica" modes that intensify as wire length decreases. The effective interaction strength in the wires is adjusted by varying 1D inter-subband screening by over 45%.

$context$. The assembly history of the Milky Way is now being revealed through data from the $Gaia$ mission. The globular cluster system likely followed an equally complex formation path. $aims$. To constrain this path, we examine the connection between globular clusters and the Milky Way’s known merging events. $methods$. We combine $Gaia$'s kinematic data for nearly all galactic clusters with the largest sample of cluster ages, corrected for systematic errors. To identify clusters of common origin, we analyze their dynamical properties, focusing on integrals of motion. $results$. We find that roughly 40% of the clusters likely formed in situ.

The estimation of a dataset's intrinsic dimension is a fundamental step in most dimensionality reduction techniques. This article introduces *intrinsic*, an R package that implements state-of-the-art likelihood-based estimators for intrinsic dimension. Specifically, the package includes the TWO-NN, GRIDE, and HIDALGO models. To ensure accessibility, *intrinsic* provides high-level, intuitive functions built on efficient low-level routines. The package features two categories of estimators: homogeneous and heterogeneous. The first includes TWO-NN and GRIDE, with functions supporting both frequentist and Bayesian inference. The second category comprises HIDALGO, a Bayesian mixture model, for which an efficient Gibbs sampler is implemented.

Spintronic nanodevices exhibit ultrafast nonlinear dynamics and recurrence behaviors on a nanosecond scale, enabling promising applications in spintronic reservoir computing (RC). Here, two physical RC systems—one based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (MSM) and another using 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNOs)—were modeled for image classification and nonlinear dynamic system prediction, respectively. Micromagnetic simulations of MSM and STNO responses to current pulses demonstrate that an RC system with a single MSM achieves outstanding performance in handwritten digit recognition. Moreover, a physical RC system comprising 24 STNOs effectively solves complex nonlinear dynamic problems, as validated by second-order nonlinear dynamic and NARMA10 tasks.

Ranking algorithms play a vital role in online platforms, from search engines to recommender systems. This paper reveals an unexpected outcome of popularity-based rankings: the fewer the items reporting a signal, the greater their collective share of traffic. This few-get-richer effect arises when there are limited distinct item classes (e.g., left-leaning vs. right-leaning news sources) and rankings depend on popularity. We analytically show this effect occurs when users click top-ranked items and exhibit diverse class preferences. Through simulations, we examine how the effect’s strength varies with contextual and behavioral assumptions. We also validate our predictions experimentally with human participants. These findings offer critical insights into misinformation spread.

Weight pruning is widely recognized as a simple yet effective method to reduce redundancy in deep neural networks (DNNs), enabling acceleration across various platforms. However, most pruning techniques compromise between model accuracy and regularity, often resulting in reduced inference accuracy and limited on-device acceleration. To address this, we introduce a novel sparsity dimension—pattern-based sparsity, combining pattern and connectivity sparsity—which achieves both high accuracy and hardware efficiency. By employing carefully designed patterns, our pruning method consistently enhances accuracy and improves feature extraction across diverse DNN architectures and datasets. Additionally, our pattern-aware framework simultaneously handles pattern library extraction, selection, pruning, and weight training. This approach naturally aligns with compiler optimizations for efficient DNN execution on mobile platforms.

Difference-in-differences analysis with a control group that significantly differs from the treated group risks bias from historical events affecting the groups differently. Creating a more closely matched control group by selecting a subset of the overall controls may reduce this bias. We investigate this phenomenon through simulation studies. Specifically, we examine the impact of mountaintop removal mining (MRM) on mortality using a difference-in-differences approach, leveraging the rise in MRM after the 1990 Clean Air Act amendments. For our analysis of MRM's effect on mortality, we developed a better-matched control group and obtained a 95% confidence interval encompassing substantial adverse effects, no effect, and minor beneficial effects.

When building models to summarize clinical data for simulations, it is essential to assess their ability to reproduce the data. This can be achieved using visual predictive checks (VPC), which involve (1) simulating multiple replicates of the original study from the model, (2) computing key estimates for each simulated study, and (3) comparing their distribution with the original estimate. This approach is a versatile and generally straightforward method. Here, we explore its application to time-to-event data, particularly when a time-varying covariate is unknown or cannot be approximated post-event.

Novel concepts, perspectives, and challenges in measuring and controlling open quantum systems through sequential schemes are presented. We demonstrate how similar protocols, combining repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses, enable: (i) confining and protecting quantum dynamics from decoherence in line with Zeno physics; (ii) analytically predicting the probability of transferring a quantum system into a target state via stochastic sequential measurements; (iii) optimally reconstructing environmental noise spectral density by orthogonalizing frequency-domain filter functions for quantum sensors. These advancements will improve our ability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, driving progress in quantum science and technologies.

Palms sweaty, heart racing, stomach in knots. You can't cry for help—not only is your throat too tight to breathe, but it'd be humiliating. No, you aren't being stalked by a monster; you're speaking in public, a fate some consider worse than death. When you're dead, you feel nothing; at a podium, you feel stage fright. But we’ve all had to speak before others, so you must learn to overcome it. First, understand stage fright. As social creatures, we’re wired to care about reputation. Public speaking threatens that. Before a speech, you panic: *What if they think I’m awful?*

I can't think of anyone who has just one interest in life and wants to pursue only that forever. [The way we work], about 15% of American workers don't have traditional full-time jobs—they're part-time, contract workers, or temps. The term 'side hustle' fits this ethos, where people combine multiple gigs to earn a living. The phrase 'side hustle' originated in popular African American newspapers. In the 1920s, 'hustle' referred to scams, but by the 1950s, 'side hustle' described legitimate work too. Unlike a second job driven by necessity, a side hustle offers flexibility.

Two twin domes, two radically opposed design cultures. One is crafted from thousands of steel parts, the other woven from a single silk thread. One is synthetic, the other organic. One imposes on the environment, the other shapes it. One is designed for nature, the other by her. Michelangelo believed raw marble held figures yearning to break free. His chisel was his sole tool. Yet living things are not carved—they grow. Within our cells, the smallest units of life, lies all the information needed for function and replication. Tools carry consequences. Since the Industrial Revolution, design has been ruled by the demands of manufacturing and mass production.

Hello. My name is Simone. You know how people say if you get nervous onstage, picture the audience naked? It’s supposed to help, but imagining all of you naked in 2018 feels weird and wrong. We’re working hard to move past that, so we need a better way to handle stage fright. I realized what I’d really like is to look at you as much as you look at me—just to balance things out. If I had way more eyeballs, we’d all be comfortable, right?

To do two things at once is to do neither." This biting critique of multitasking is often credited to the Roman writer Publilius Syrus—though, as with many quotes, he likely never said it. What fascinates me, however, is whether it holds true. Certainly, it applies to emailing at dinner, texting while driving, or live-tweeting a TED Talk. Yet I’d argue that for certain vital tasks, doing two—or even three or four—things at once is ideal. Consider Albert Einstein: in 1905, he published four groundbreaking scientific papers.

I know this may sound unusual, but I believe robots can inspire us to be better humans. I grew up in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, home of Bethlehem Steel. My father, an engineer, taught me how things worked. Together, we built projects like model rockets and slot cars. Here’s the go-kart we built—that’s me behind the wheel with my sister and best friend. When I was about 10, he came home and announced at dinner that our next project would be... a robot.

Sustainability defines the what, where, and how of what is caught. The who and why matter most to me. I want to know the people behind my meals, how I affect them, and how they affect me. I want to understand why they fish and how they depend on the water’s bounty for survival. Grasping this shifts our view of seafood—from a commodity to a chance to heal our ecosystem. It lets us cherish the seafood we’re lucky to enjoy. So what do we call this? I call it restorative seafood. While sustainability is about enduring, restoration is about replenishing and progressing.

The starving orphan pleading for a second helping of gruel. The spinster fading away in her tattered wedding gown. The miser, hardened by greed, haunted by the ghost of Christmas past. More than a century after his death, these remain iconic figures from Charles Dickens's works. His writing is so distinctive that it inspired its own adjective. But what makes Dickens's prose so remarkable? His fiction thrives on suspense, crafted through atmospheric settings, unexpected turns, and enigmatic plots. These elements captivated readers, leaving them eager for more. Originally, his tales were serialized—released in affordable literary journals chapter by chapter before being compiled into books.

Shah Rukh Khan: Courage, determination, and a single-minded vision. These are the qualities the greatest achievers share. These are the brave hearts for whom failure is never an option. What seems like an unconquerable sea to us is, for our next speaker, an irresistible stage she was born to command. Let’s dive into the story of fearless speaker Bhakti Sharma, who’s making waves in long-distance swimming. Bhakti Sharma. (Applause)  

Bhakti Sharma: Imagine, in Rajasthan’s scorching heat, a two-and-a-half-year-old riding a moped behind her mother, unaware of their destination. Twenty minutes later, she finds herself submerged in water.

I'm going to discuss a technology we're developing at Oxford that we believe will revolutionize computer games and Hollywood movies. This technology simulates humans—complete with virtual bodies and nervous systems to control them. Before delving deeper, let's examine how human characters currently appear in games. Here's a clip from *Grand Theft Auto 3*, which we briefly saw yesterday. As you'll notice, it's an excellent game and one of the most successful ever made.

Like many people around the world, earlier this summer my friends and I were captivated by the Women's World Cup in France. We watched these incredible athletes deliver amazing goals in clean, engaging matches. Meanwhile, off the field, they advocated for equal pay—or, in some cases, any pay at all for their sport. Obsessed, we chose a Spanish-speaking network in the U.S. to watch the games live. A few matches in, a friend asked, "Why does it feel like everything I'm seeing is ads for makeup, cleaning products, and diets?

I want to tell you about the future of money. Let's begin with a story about a culture in Micronesia during the early 1900s, called the Yap. Their form of money is fascinating—they used limestone discs known as Rai stones. Unlike our coins, the Yap didn’t physically exchange these stones because they could be enormous. The largest weighed about four tons and spanned 12 feet. Instead, they simply tracked ownership. There’s even a tale of sailors transporting a stone that sank during a storm.

You’ve been accused of a crime you did not commit. Proving your innocence is impossible. If you maintain your innocence, you’ll likely be convicted and executed. But if you confess, apologize, and implicate others, you’ll go free. Do you lie—or risk a public hanging? This was the dilemma for those accused of witchcraft in Salem, Massachusetts, between February 1692 and May 1693. They fell victim to supernatural paranoia, misguided religious zeal—and a justice system that prized repentance over truth. Salem was founded in 1626 by Puritans, English Protestants. Life there was rigid and isolated. Conflicts with Native American neighbors and French settlers were frequent.

There are currently hundreds of thousands of people on transplant lists, waiting for critical organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers that could save their lives. Unfortunately, donor organs remain scarce, unable to meet this urgent demand. What if, instead of waiting, we could create customized organs from scratch? That’s the promise of bioprinting, an emerging branch of regenerative medicine. While we can’t yet print complex organs, simpler tissues like blood vessels and nutrient-exchange tubes are already achievable. Bioprinting is a biological counterpart to 3D printing, layering materials to construct three-dimensional objects step by step.

Good afternoon, I'm honored to be here at TEDxKrakow. Today, I'll discuss a phenomenon that is actively changing the world: people power. I'll begin with an anecdote—or for Monty Python fans, a sketch-like story. It's December 15, 2010. Someone offers you a bet: gaze into a crystal ball to see an accurate future, but you must share it with the world. Curiosity wins; you accept. An hour later, you're on national TV recounting the vision.

We begin in 1964. Bob Dylan, 23, is at the peak of his career. Hailed as the voice of a generation, he produces timeless songs at an astonishing pace. Yet a small group claims he steals others' work.  

In 2004, Brian Burton (Danger Mouse) merges The Beatles' *White Album* with Jay-Z's *Black Album*, creating *The Grey Album*. It quickly goes viral, but The Beatles' label issues cease-and-desist letters for "unfair competition and property dilution." Today, *The Grey Album* stands as a remix.

Well, that’s a rather obvious statement. I began with that sentence about 12 years ago, focusing initially on developing countries, but you’re here from every corner of the world. If you picture a map of your country, you’ll realize that for every nation, you could mark areas where good teachers won’t go. Moreover, these are often the same places where trouble arises. It’s an ironic problem—good teachers avoid the very areas that need them most. In 1999, I started addressing this issue with a simple experiment in New Delhi.

Currently, most refugees reside in cities rather than camps, representing over 60% of refugees worldwide. With the majority in urban areas, a paradigm shift is urgently needed. Instead of wasting resources on barriers, investing in self-reliance programs would be far more effective. (Applause) We often leave behind possessions, but never our skills and knowledge. Given the opportunity, refugees can thrive and contribute to their host nations. I was born in Bukavu, South Kivu, in the Democratic Republic of Congo, as the fifth of twelve children.

I have two questions for you. First: whose shoulders do you stand on? Second: what do you stand for? These are the questions I open my poetry workshops with because poetry can sometimes feel like a relic, reserved for old white men who seem born aged—like Benjamin Button. I ask my students these questions, then share my own answers in three lines: I am the daughter of Black writers, descended from freedom fighters who broke chains and changed the world. They call me. These words become my mantra before every poetry performance—I was even reciting them earlier, making faces in the corner.

(Laughter) I was a self-employed living statue called the Eight-Foot Bride, and I love telling people about it because everyone wonders, *Who are these people in real life?* (Laughter) Hello.  

One day, I painted myself white, stood on a box, placed a hat or can at my feet, and when someone dropped in money, I gave them a flower—and intense eye contact. If they didn’t take it, I added a gesture of sadness and longing as they walked away.

On October 4, 1957, the world watched in awe as the Soviet Union launched Sputnik, humanity's first artificial satellite, into space. This small metal sphere, less than two feet wide, ignited an 18-year space race between the U.S. and U.S.S.R., reshaping our world. However, Sputnik wasn't the first human-made object in space. That distinction belongs to Germany's V-2 rocket, deployed in WWII's final years against Allied cities.
